div3.head: Another Yankee letter.
div3.p:
The following letter was taken from the body of a dead Federalist, after the battle at Manassas, on Sunday last.
It was addressed to "Mrs. Jedd P. C. Cottrell, Milwaukie, Wisconsin." On the envelope was printed the following:
"If any one attempts to haul down the American flag, shoot him on the spot."--John A. Dix.

div4.p:
I received your letter yesterday, and with the greatest of pleasure.
You do not know how happy it makes our boys feel to hear from our friends and relatives.
I have not received but three letters from home since I left, but I have through other mediums.
We are encamped in a very nice grove.
Our company is about half a mile from the rest of the regiment, and are acting as a picket guard.
The regiment is encamped in an open field, and is almost roasted every day, as the weather is very hot in the day time, and it rains most every night, and we have to sleep in the open air, as we left our tents in Alexandria, and we arrived here at 10 o'clock P. M, after a march of seven miles, and we marched it in one hour and ten minutes. We come in double quick time the most of the time.
The reason of our coming so quick was, that we heard carron and a ke in this direction, but we were too late, for the United States troops had retreat with the loss of twenty killed and thirty-two wounded. This brigade was in the advance, at they had a nigger guide, and he led them on a masked battery, and they cut two companies all to pieces before they could retreat from their lines.
We are encamped about three miles from them, and seven miles from Manassas Junction, and we shall attack them to-morrow or the next day. Our division is fortifying on a hill, one mile from the enemy's line, we shall receive a lot of tar shell.
(I do not know what they are.) They have been invented once this war commenced, by a man in New York, and are very destructive.

We have now about 50,000 men in our division, and shall have from Washington 40,000 more before night.
Gen. Scott is here, and taking charge of the army, and as long as he stays with us we shall be all right.

We have got one hundred pieces of cannon and about four hundred cavalry.
We are very sure of routing the enemy, and we are confident that we shall be in Richmond in one month from this time.

The enemy is well fortified and has plenty of provision and arms, and we shall have some hard fights before we get through; but we are enough for them.
They have not shown much courage as yet. They have run before us as fast as they heard we were coming, until we got here, and I do not think they will make much of a stand here; but I do not know.

I suppose you have heard of our journey from Burlington to Washington, and it will be needless to give you a description of it; and all I have to say about it is, that we were well received everywhere with the exception of Baltimore, where we marched through the city in double file with loaded guns.
We are the heaviest regiment that I have seen yet, and I have seen about one hundred, and we are praised everywhere we go for our good behavior and drill.
The most of the troops are riotous and disorderly, but our boys are very orderly and quiet, and we have got good officers, with the exception of our Colonel; he is a regular Methodist tyrant; but since we have come into the brigade he has kept very quiet; he marched us through Washington with our knapsacks on, when the thermometer stood 112 in the shade; the distance was three miles, and Gen. Scott saw us, and the next day he told the Colonel that if he did any such thing again that he would have his command taken away from him.

We are the only troops that have marched with our knapsacks on in this country; but we stood it better with them on than a good many did without them, and we have as few sick as any regiment that I know of John B. Page and three other gentlemen from Rutland, are in our camp waiting to see the battle.
They are on a pleasure excursion through this country, and are enjoying themselves highly.
When we came through Alexandria, I visited the Marshall House, where Ellsworth was shot, and got a piece of the stair that he stood on, and sent it home to the folks.
The city is under martial law. Ellsworth's men are our advance guard; but they cannot be kept anywhere a great while at a time.
They scour the country all over and steal everything that they can lay their hands to. They have stolen horses, and niggers, and cattle, and hogs by the dozen, and they will go into houses and take all of the provisions that they can find.

When we were camped at Alexandria, four of them went to the house of a farmer, and the folks had their breakfast on the table all ready to eat, and the men went in took off their hats, and bid the folks "good morning," and sat down to the table and cleared it of every eatable; got up, and bid them "good bye," and left as cool as if the meal was prepared on purpose for them.
We should starve if it were not for them; they bring us cattle of every description.
They think a good deal of this regiment, and give us a good many things that they steal.
We have not had half army rations since we have been in the service.
Mother sent me a box of cakes and cheese, but that kind of stuff does not amount to much with us. We miss potatoes and other vegetables the most of anything but do not get half enough of anything from.
The Government.
It is so with all the troops.
But I must close this scribble, as I have got to write one home.
You must write often and I will write as often as I get a chance.
If I am discharged in this country alive and well within a year, I shall go to the Western country and make you a visit, and shall stop somewhere in hat country.

I must close by sending much love to all, and accept much yourself.
I should like to have seen you before I left home very much If you can read this letter you can do better than I can. I could not get any ink to write with.
But I must bid you good-bye for the present.
div4.closer:
W. H. H. C.
From your affectionate bro.,
P. S.--Direct to Washington.
The lady to whom the above letter is addressed can procure the original by addressing J. R. Beal, or Postmaster, Scottsville, Albemarle,
Va. P. M.

div3.head: A brave man.

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch:

div3.p:
--In the absence of "official returns" of the killed and wounded of our brave soldiers of the battle of Manassas, for which your correspondent has most impatiently waited.
I now, in justice to a noble young friend beg to be permitted to inform his friends and companions, that Jos. A. Brua. late a citizen of Jefferson county, a native of Harper's Ferry, in that county, whose whole life, before the 19th of April last, was devoted with energy and industry to the "old concern. and which was equally devoted to the O. S. A. even up to the evacuation of Harper's Ferry by Gen. Johnston, having no time or opportunity to ally himself with a regularly organizized company attached himself to Col. Gordon's Staff, and marched on foot from Winchester to Bull Run, with his musket and knapsack, and succeeded in his great wish to participate in the battle.

From the fact of his name not occurring on the rolls of a regiment, his severely wounded body has not yet been noticed.
A Minnie ball in the hip, which passed entirely through it, for the time disabled him; but, thanks to the kindness of--,into whose private dwelling he was removed, and the faithful attendance of skillful physicians, his wound is in a fair way of healing; but he will have it, that come what may, even on crutches, he is bound to be in the next contest, unless it occurs before he is out of bed. Many hearts are bound up in his welfare, and I trust that they all will be gratified in his deliverance from death in the struggle.

div3.head: Handsome compliment to a gallant son of Richmond.
div3.p:
The Richmond correspondent of the Petersburg Express notices, as follows, a flattering compliment to Lt. Raleigh Travers Daniel, Jr., of this city.
The compliment was one well merited, and it was paid in a handsome manner by the noble North Carolinians:

"I understand that the Grauville (N. C) Grays, stationed near Norfolk, have presented an elegant sword to Lt. Raleigh Travers Daniel, Jr., of this city.
Lieut Daniel has been acting as Drill Sergeant for the Grays, and bad endeared himself to every member by his urbans demeanor and uniform kindness — The sword cost $100, and was presented by Dr. Samuel Williams, who delivered a very neat and appropriate speech on the occasion.
Lt. Daniel responded in a feeling and appropriate manner.
Lt. Daniel has returned to this city, and contemplates raising a company for active service.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
abundant crops — large religious Meetings.
div3.p:
I have within a few days passed through five or six counties, South of James river, and have been filled with wonder at the immense crops under which the land seems to be groaning.
The old people say they never have known before such corn.
One man who will probably have a thousand barrels for sale, says that he hopes that it will sell for about 12 cents per bushel; that all he wants now is to see the Southern Confederacy sustained, and that corn will aid in that.
Another says he attributes the extraordinary crops of the present year to the fact that the "Giver of all good." is thus showing His approval of the South in throwing off the chains of slavery and chastising its oppressor.

The Baptists of the Dan River Association are now holding their twenty third annual meeting in this neighborhood.
Rev. J. T. McLaughlin is moderator.
The churches of this county report upwards of 2,000 communicants, and in a prosperous condition.--There are present three returned missionaries from China and Africa, a delegate from Texas, and visiting brethren from North Carolina and Virginia.
Yesterday the religious wants of our soldiers engaged the attention of the body, and a liberal collection was made.
It was stated that within a few weeks the Baptist Colporiage Board in Richmond had sent 400,000 pages of religious tracts among the soldiers, and that now they are publishing a selection of hymns and an edition of the New Testament for the same purpose.
This is certainly a most important work, and every true Southern man ought to rejoice that so much is being done for the souls of those who, amid the dangers and temptations of camp life, are now defending the rights and honor of the South.

There are many glad hearts through this country since the glorious news from Bull Run and Manassas.
The people are ready to give themselves and all they have to the good cause of breaking down the Lincoln Government. *

div3.head: The gallant dead.
div3.p:
The ceremonies in Charleston, S. C. on the arrival of the remains of General Bee, General Bartow and Lieut. Col. Johnson, were most solemn and impressive.
After giving a description of the procession, the Courier says:

q.p:
The bodies were borne to the have of the Church, the Rev. C. P. Gadsden reading the usual Episcopal burial service.
The Church was filled to repletion, and every available foot of space occupied.

The lesson for the day was read in the most impressive manner by the Rev Mr. Gadsden, from the first chapter of the first Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians, commencing with, "Now is Christ risen from the dead and become the first fruits of them that slept." The usual services of the Church were varied with the following soul-stirring address, which we have the pleasure of laying before our readers:

We stand, my friends, in the presence of a great sorrow. The tidings of victory, which have been borne from the hard-fought field, where the gallant defenders of our country have, through the blessing of God, driven back the armies of the invader, have, as is too often the case, been mi g ed with the heavy news of the loss of our citizens.
The shout of triumph is accompanied with the wail of the bereaved the laurels of our heroes are bedewed with the tears of their widows and orphans.
Terrible result of war!
sad effects of sin; mournful tokens of our fallen estate! "God alone is great;" only the triumph of His cause are unmixed with grief.

You have gathered here to do becoming honor to the earthly remains of patriot eroes — They responded to their country's call to defend her liberties; and they have fallen, doing all their duty to their native land.
Their heroism will be a legacy to their children; their names a treasure to the Republic.
We mourn their untimely end, but we feel that the cause for which they fought has been rendered more sacred by their fall.

This is no occasion to appeal to your patriotism, or to seek to animate your devotion to liberty and law. I stand here as a Minister of Christ to point you to the sad ravages of sin, and remind you that all those evil passions from which spring tyranny and oppression, are the mournful off acts of man's apostasy from God.
I stand here, by these precious remains, to bid you put your trust in the Lord and seek to be reconciled to him through his Son. I would embrace so impressive an occasion to admonish our brave soldiers, who may soon be called into the field, that thoughts of Eternity must not be shut out from their hearts by the grave and pressing duties of Time.
God speaks to us by his Providence in a voice to which we must hearken.
In the sight of victory, in the sound of triumph and the dazzling light of glory, he shows us the grave--Time is but the vestibule of eternity — earth the preparation for heaven.
Through death must we pass to life.
The terrible tyrant of the human race, how savage is thy mein, how full of a we h countenance!
But light from the Sun of Righteousness bridges the cloud of darkness with the bow of promise, and the Cross of Jesus subdues the tyrant into the servant and messenger of God.

There is a victory greater than any earth has chronicled — it is the victory of Immanuel over the grave.
There is One mightier than Death — omnipotent even over sin.

You have bound the laurel of the Palmetto on your hero's biers, fit emblems of valor devoted to the State we love.
But there are garlands more enduring than these, wreaths that cannot wither, coronals of glory and palm branches of immortal victory.
Let us be candidates for these.
Let death, with its solemn, appalling tread, bring us a message of comfort, a watchword of peace. "If Jesus died and rose again, even so them also which sleep in Jesus will God bring with Him." "Oh, death where is thy sting?
on grave where is thy victory?
The sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law; but thanks be to God which giveth us the victory through Jesus Christ our Lord"

Go lay your heroes to their repose; shed over them the tears of a deep regret; treasure for your State the memory of their valor; tell your children of their self sacrificing bravery; hang the laurel and the cypress upon their tombs; resolve to emulate their bold devotion to their country's liberties, and take with you from their resting place the recollection of the Conqueror of Death; make your peace with God in Christ, and be prepared, in His strength, for whatever may befall you; to do and to suffer in behalf of those great trusts which the Almighty has committed to you as he shall order
Let Christ be the portion of your souls, and God your refuge and defence.
Thus, while affection weeps and patriotism honors, let piety learn a lesson of improvement, and faith be instructed, under all adversities, to hold fast by God.

My friends, it is no occasion for words.--Our hearts are full, and there are hearts more bitterly wrung then ours.
May God have mercy on and comfort them.
May the sympathy of Jesus be experienced by all who mourn the ravages of this unnatural war.--May Heaven console when earth is impotent, and Christ give strength where it has been so graciously promised in those words of holy comfort, "As thy day so shall thy strength be"

div3.head: Effect of the late battle.
div3.p: --The following extract is from the Toronto Leader (Canada:)

Of course, the success will give the rebels more confidence, increase their ardor, give additional troops to their standard, confirm waverers, and induce greater sacrifices on the part of the people to sustain the cause in which they are engaged.
The influence of Generals Beauregard and Johnston will be in creased; no unimportant consideration, when it is remembered that one of the first requisites to success in military matters is, that the soldiers should have confidence in their leaders.
Hitherto, necessarily untried men have been employed on both sides.
The result of the first serious encounter indicates — we cannot say it proves — that the best Generals are those on the side of the South.
A great moral gain is therefore with the Confederates.
They are stronger now than they have ever been since the contest commenced.

They have, however, done good service to the National cause.
The people of the North have been too confident — They imagined that their enemies could be swept off the face of the earth with the greatest possible ease — Foreigners have never seen any reason to believe that American citizens of the South were to any great degree inferior in courage to those of the North.
Yet the Unionists have, by repeatedly reiterating the accusation, convinced themselves that all the traitors were arrant cowards.

div3.head: The Wise Legion.
div3.p:
--A correspondent of the Dispatch, writing from Jackson's river, urges the necessity of sending immediate reinforcements to Gen. Wise.
He is in a country where traitors abound, while a large Federal force is not far distant from his position.
Our correspondent adds:

q.p:
"I cannot close without saying something in behalf of my friends Isaac and Thomas Ste re, contractors on the V. C. R. R, who have done all in their power for the Southern cause.
They say — Come and take all the wagons and mules and horses we have, if you need them, to carry arms, ammunition and supplies to the Wise Legion.
This they have done without charge to the State.
These are men of the right spirit.
Would that we had more of them here."

div3.head: Attempt of an English Baron to murder his own son.
div3.p: The Baron Alfred Louis Pons de Vidil, known in society as an Orleanist, settled in England, and practically naturalized by marriage six-and-twenty years ago in a wealthy Hertfordshire family of Jacksons, is now a fugitive in France from English officers of justice, by whom he is charged with an attempt at highway murder on his only son.

The Baron's wife died early, leaving a son heir, upon his coming of age, to a large part of her property; the reversion being to the father if the son died without heirs.
The son is now a graduate of Cambridge, twenty-three years old, fully entitled to expect an account of his father's stewardship.
Yesterday fortnight the father, living a bachelor's life at the Clarendon, sent to his son a chambers in Jermyn street, inviting him to breakfast with him, and then go with him to call at Claremont upon the ex-Queen of France.
At Claremont they put up their horses, made their call, chatted for nearly an hour with the Duc d'orleans, returned to the inn remounted, and turned homeward at a walking pace.
On their way back it appears that the father lost his way designedly.
Finally, they met a woman who told them they were astray; they retraced their steps, and got into other lanes that brought them to the back of Orleans House, by the stables.
They then turned on one side, and the son supposed that his father was going round to the main entrance.
Presently they turned a sharp corner in the lane, and found themselves in an enclosure of read, with another sharp corner not far before them.

At this first corner the father halted as the son rode on. The father called to his son Alfred that they were all wrong and must turn back.
The youth turned back, and had returned only a few paces when he received a violent blow and looked up to see his father advancing on him, with something uplifted in his hand, to strike again.
The second blow fell, the youth's hat was off and his forehead streaming with blood, but his spurned horse rose to intercept on its own head the third blow, and at that moment a laboring man and woman came round the opposite corner.

The man, John Rivers, saw the elder strike the younger on the forehead with something which he took to be a whip handle that glittered at the end. The youth, slipping off his horse, rushed to the feet of the woman for protection.
Close by was John Evans, a bargeman, to whom the son next clung, crying "Help me!
Protect me!
Save me!" When the youth was questioned, he saw his father looking intently at him, saying something about a wall and a fall John Everett, an other laborer, came up, and seeing the wounded youth of course asked, "How did it happen?" The father replied that the young gentleman had stood up in his saddle to look over a wall, that the horse reared, and so he fell To Evans he said that the horse shied and threw the boy against the wall.

When the youth's wounds were being roughly washed he shrunk in terror from the father's desire to take part in that attention, and when a surgeon came he begged that his assistant might be sent with him to town.

For a week the Baron de Vidil lived as usual at the Clarendon.
In the meantime the son had told his story, and Inspector Thornton, of the detective force, had found the evidence in confirmation.
At the beginning of this week the Baron was a fugitive, and the detectives are upon his track in Paris.

div3.head: Dr. W. H. Hoge.
div3.p: --The following is the letter of Dr. Hoge to his congregation in New York, resigning his pastorship:
For some time I have contemplated a resignation of my pastoral charge in the Brick Church.

I have only waited to discover the will of Providence consequents of a radical difference between my sentiments and those of my people in the great isms and those of the day. I yet remembered that my Master called me to preach the gospels as His ambassador, and not to discuss any political question, however absorbing.
On this ground I have steadfastly stood.

For a time I was induced by the entreaties and representations of many friends, in whose judgment and faithfulness I conflict, to believe that a majority of my people were willing to place the gospel above the national question, and earnestly desired me to continue to serve them in the gospel.

But since it has become manifest that a pastor whose political views, though never obtruded, are opposed to them, but can no longer labor with comfort among them, I request in Session to take the necessary steps to obtain the consent of the congregation, and a united application to the Presbytery for the dissolution of my pastoral relation.

div3.head: European opinion.
div3.p: --The Dublin Times, on July 12th, commenting on American affairs, says:

q.p:
Dr Russell.
writing from the South, speaks of the improved feeling towards England.
In the North the same hostility, unaccountable as it is, is persistently manifested.
The State Department is persistently occupied with foreign affairs, as if it had not abundant to employ itself in domestic affairs.
The important naval and military movements along the extended coasts of America, and the Canadian frontier, have given umbrage to the Administration; and we are informed that, in the event of any interference on the part of her Majesty's squadron, "England will be taught a lesson that she will not very soon forget" In fact, the Americans of the North, irritated by the successful resistance of the Southerners, are ready peevishly to quarrel with every nation.
Spain has not replied to the note of the Government respecting San Domingo. England and France understand the designs of the Spanish Government, and lend their countenance to them.
No people ever exhibited themselves so impotent with regard to these who have revolted from them as the Northerners, and certainly no people harangue with greater arrogance against powers which pity them, but leave them to themselves.

div3.head: An Apparent Decree of fate
div3.p:
--We have just learned of the drowning of William Hughes, a sailor belonging to the Confederate States Navy, and attached to the receiving ship of war St. Phillip, on Monday evening last, under circumstances that would induce many to believe that the inexorable hand of fate had decreed his death by drowning on that day. In the morning he was crossing the river from this city to Algiers on one of the ferry boats, and while standing near the edge of the guards accidently lost his balance and fell into the river.
The engines were reversed, the boat stopped, and by great exertions on the part of those on board he was rescued and soon recovered from his immersion.
In the evening, on board of the St. Phillip, the lieutenant in command called his men together to read to them the extra containing President Davis's announcement of the victory at Manassas.
They gave three hearty cheers, and then were told to wait and "splice the main brace" While the grog was being prepared for them Hughes asked the lieutenant to let him see the extra, and it was given to him — While standing at the head of the gangway, reading it in the dusk of the evening, he fell over backward into the water, and sunk to be seen no more.
The depression of the men's spirits, caused by this accident, made them postpone their jollification over the victory.--

div3.head: Cavalry
div3.p:
--If President Davis has in view any important enterprise, demanding a large force of cavalry armed with rifle, or double-barreled gun and sabre, for six months achieve service from the 1st of September or October next, we would suggest that it is highly probable that North Carolina could furnish 5,000 such troops at short notice after the crops are disposed of. Many of our readers are expert riders, and many of them are practiced shots of horseback with rifle and double-barreled gun. A force of this kind with good sabres, would be a most formidable body of troops, and with ordinary Southern daring and courage, could sweep off entire fields of Yankee infantry — or keep the enemy's scouts and pickets in close quarters, or put the flanks of a moving army or foraging parties to infinite damage.
It is said, that the charge of only 1,500 Southern cavalry upon the enemy's line at Manassas the other day was terribly sublime.
Eyewitnesses think the charge baffles conception.
What, in like circumstances, could 5,000 or 10,000 cavalry accomplish?
The only difficulty is in equipping them; but these may be gotten up on a cheap scale.--Raleigh Standard.

div3.head: A fatal prize
div3.p:
--The Cracow journals announce the death in that city of a man named Brikowski, who won the great prize of 250,000 florins in the Austrian lottery last year.
To obtain immediate possession of his fortune be paid a discount of 11,000 florins, but from the moment he got it in his possession he seems never to have enjoyed a moments peace, so fearful was he that some robber would strip him of his unexpected wealth.
He kept it in an iron chest, locked up in an arched vault, and visited it morning and night, to see that all was safe, till at last, from excitement and anxiety, he fell ill, and typhus supervening, death soon delivered him from all his troubles.

div3.head: American purchase as of French arms
div3.p: --The Paris correspondent of the New York Times says that muskets which were offered at the standard price of 45 francs-- ine dollars — when the American agents first arrived in France and Belgium, have now augmented to 75 francs--fifteen dollars. This is partly due to the fact that Mr. Butler King bids against the agents of the Northern States, and that the agents of these States even bid against each other.

div3.head: The Lincoln Administration — the war party at the North.
div3.p: The New York Daily News lashes the Lincoln Administration after this fashion:

His whole Administration has been characterized by all the contemptible littleness and dissimulation, the dirty cabals and the degrading plottings of a County Convention, rather than by the open, high-minded generous operations of true statesmanship — The low cunning that masked its dealings with the Southern Commissioners in the duplicity of promising a pacific settlement, and under cover of such promise masking its active preparations to precipitate a collision — its contemptible ruse of pretending that Washington was in hourly danger of capture, to stimulate and madden the Northern mind against the South--these have shown a most lamentable want of honesty of purpose.
All this has been most adroitly seconded by the Message of the President, where the suppression of the truth is only surpassed by the assertion of what is false.--That Message is characterized by all those peculiarities for which Mr. Lincoln is so notorious, and is more worthy to emanate from the tortuous mind of some wire- puller of a political caches than from an individual who holds the elevated post of President of this Republic.

The details of the Administration, also, have all been distinguished by the same narrow mindedness so characteristic of its head.
It illegal arrests, its persecutions of private individuals without color of law — its seizure of presses by its military hirelings — its war upon pastors and churches in Virginia — its uniform, systematic and manifold corruptions — its conspiracy bills and its gag laws, can find no parallel even in all the delinquencies of the Hastings' Administration in India.
To all these sins of commission must be that startling sin of omission, the refusal to listen to the voice of conciliation and compromise, thus involving the people in all the horrors of civil war. Before that bloody war shall end, with the immense hordes of contractors, jobbers and swiddlers in its train, it will be said of this Administration, as was said of the East India Government by the indignant Burke--"it wielded a bloody truncheon in one hand, while it was busy picking the nation's pocket with the other."
In another article, the News says:

q.p:
The very principles of our nature, the very passions of our souls, cry aloud against the insane folly of this war party of the North--Whenever the flesh will not quiver when the pincers tear, and the blood will not follow when the knife is driven, then will the insane theory have some chance for its establishment, but not before.
The unprincipled, corrupt leaders do not believe it themselves.
They only keep up the cry to deceive and cajole their followers, until the time shall arrive when, protected by their four or five hundred thousand bayonets, they can declare their grand scheme of emancipation — can lift "those are official weights" that are pressing so heavily upon the shoulders of their colored brethren at the South. "We will subjugate and govern them as Territories, if need be," said the bosom friend of Lincoln in the Senate; "and it emancipation must come, why, then let it come" But an overrunning Providence, we trust, will never suffer Northern fanaticism to make such a stri as this.
May it be arrested before, in its madness, it shall have found power to work such irremediable mischief.

div3.head: The "Hydra Headed Monster."
div3.p:
--The Washing on correspondent of the Baltimore Exchange writes that Gen. Scott gives out to his friends that the next blow struck at the Confederates will crush all life from the "hydra-headed monster." It is intended to make the army of the Potomac 100,000 strong; the army of the Shenandoah (Banks') 40,000, and to collect 50,000 men in the Valley of Western Virginia.
A concerted movement is to be made by these forces, in conjunction with the Mississippi and Ohio flutilles.
Gen. Scott insists on taking his time, which will probably how be allowed him by the press of the North, though Secretaries Blair and Chase were anions to know from the Lieutenant-General where the next blow would be struck.
Scott does not at a hany blame to Gen. M. Dowell, on either the charge of cowardice or that of inability.

div3.head: A good Sign.
div3.p: --Judge Samuel Pickens, who has been reported is favorable to rebellion, made a speech in Marysville, Tenn., last Saturday, taking string grounds against rebellion — and also against East Tennessee separation in any other than a peaceable, constitutional way; also, expressed himself much opposed to Lincoln troops being introduced into East Tennessee.

div3.head: National Foundry.
div3.p: The importance of a National Foundry to the Confederate Government cannot be overrated, and there is no point on this continent which presents such a combination of advantages for the location of such an establishment as the city of Richmond.

Iron, coal, water power, and facilities of transportation, of receiving and delivering, and of labor, are the great requisites for a National Foundry.
The quality of the James river iron is known to be the best for this purpose in America, and twelve miles distant is an inexhaustible supply of coal.
The late United States Government fully understood the unequaled advantages of Richmond in this respect, for without any particular partiality for Virginia, its necessities compelled it to have a large proportion of the cannon for the army and navy made here, because experience had demonstrated that our iron and shops turned out the best cannon in the country, and probably in the world.
The neighborhood of the Tredegar Works, which constructed the machinery of the largest steam frigates in the United States Navy, and which has rendered such important service in the construction of cannon for the Confederate Government, would be a suitable site for a National Foundry.
It would be upon the very margin of the canal, and commanding an amount of water power not equaled by any town in the United States.
The canal would bring to its doors the iron and coal, and carry the works manufactured for the Government from the spot where they were made to the adjoining river, or to any other point.--It ought to be borne in mind that, no matter where a National Foundry is established, James river iron and coal would have to be used, and the cost and labor increased by transporting them from this point, where they could be conveniently had, to distant and less advantageous localities.
In addition to these advantages of the best iron, coal and water power, is the fact that Richmond has an unusual number of iron foundries within her limit a some ten or a dozen of which are on a large scale, besides various minor iron works, employing a large number of foundry men, showing the existence in this city, at the very doors of the proposed foundry, of a large amount of fixed, reliable and permanently located mechanical force, growing up with our iron interests, and which, in the event of any emergency requiring extra labor, would preclude the possibility of dependence upon aid from abroad, and thereby give certainty and permanence to the operations of the Government.
The acknowledged salubrity of this city, which is found by statistics to be the healthiest city on the Atlantic seaboard, is another obvious advantage of Richmond.

We understand that the city of Richmond owns a valuable site, adjacent to the canal, which is suitable in every respect for the purpose of a National Foundry.
No doubt she would cheerfully give this location to the Confederate Government for such an object — an act of wise and patriotic liberality, which she ought not to hesitate to perform.

div3.head: The handcuffs.
div3.p:
An Albemarle correspondent, who seems in credulous about the handcuffs — thinking it hardly possible that our Northern invaders can be so barbarous as to bring manacles to place on Southern people — asks is it possible?
We answer that it is possible, and that it is true.
There are some of these handcuffs in this city.
Two most reliable gentlemen--one a surgeon in the army and one a captain, both recently from Manassas — say to us that they saw the handcuffs, and also some fetters for the feet.
As to the number of handcuffs we cannot ascertain with accuracy.
Estimates have been various.
The surgeon, not an extravagant gentleman, by any means — a man well known here, and not led away by excitement at any time — stated to us that he saw a large pile of handcuffs, he would suppose as many as a thousand, though he could not tell.
Something was said about the handcuffs to the Federal prisoners at Manassas, when one of them, with some vehemence, declared that they were not intended for the Southern people, but their own soldiers.
Great must have been the number of anticipated desertions if that were so!
It may be that handcuffs were regarded a luxury, and reserved for the Grand Army, in which case it would be fair to infer that the large stock of liquors and sweetmeats were intended for the Southern people!
If this were the intention of our kind Northern friends, then it has been carried out, so far as to place us in possession of the liquors and good things generally!
As for the handcuffs, we can, if we choose, place them on hands certainly very fit to wear them — hands of men who have voluntarily enslaved themselves to a despotism the most odious that ever cursed the earth.
But Southern people have no pleasure in employing the shackles of despots, and will not be eager to further degrade even the mercenaries of Lincoln.

Certainly the handcuffs intended for loyal Southerners are in keeping with the monstrous spirit of barbarism with which the war was inaugurated by the North.
The rope was another part of the equipment for the invasion.
When the companies and the regiments were organizing at the North during the winter, company orders for drill constantly contained the injunction upon each member to "bring hemp" with them.
Hemp was to be carried along to hang true Southern men!--Had the Northern hordes reached Richmond, those ropes would have been used!
We have not a doubt of it. Once here, they would have foolishly imagined the war was at an end, and the South subjugated.
The bittered malignity, the vilest passions, would have vented themselves upon our city.
Even that depraved old man, Winfield Scott, had his "resentment" to gratify by the woes that the brutal army he sought to let loose upon us would have visited upon cur devoted citizens.

Richmond was not taken!
Thanks to our glorious army at Manassas!
Our city was saved, and History has thus been deprived of one of the blackest chapters ever written, to excite the pity and horror of future ages.

div3.head: Excuses for defeat.
div3.p:
The Northern press has almost as many different theories to account for the late defeat as there are newspapers.
It is reasonable, as a general thing, to conclude that journalists have not much knowledge of military matters, else they would be in the army.--Men who can tell so well how a thing ought to be done, ought not to hide their light under a bushel.
The ideas of a Divine Providence, which often confounds the most subtle plane and powerful agencies of evil men, does not enter into the idea of the infidel philosophers of the Northern press.
Nevertheless it is to the blessing of God upon Southern arms, and His interposition in bringing aid at the precise time and place that it was needed, that our success war due; and He who has been our defence in the past is our reliance in the future.
The , it appears, are about to send to Europe.

div3.head: "Kiting."
div3.p:
The "Kite" is the last expedient of desperate bankrupts.
When they have no other resource they make paper to "raise the wind." Secretary Chase has got to "kiting." His Morrill tariff brings him in no money.
His United States bonds won't go upon the market except at a ruinous discount, which he is afraid to suffer.
His treasury notes have no currency.
His credit is on its last legs; and he makes his agent in Wall street "shin it" up and down those busy pavements to raise him a pitiful five millions on sixty day paper.
Mr. Cisco was engaged in that humiliating business on Monday, the 22d, when the news of Manassas came to town.
It cut him off at the knees.--He could not stir a step farther in the negotiation, and he got no money.

The necessities of a War Treasury, however, do not abate or become suspended by defeats.
Mr. Chase's wants have been aggravated, intensified and augmented by Bull Run.
Despairing of Wall street, he appeals to Boston, and he asks the bankers of that "steady" town to lend him five millions on sixty day promises.
The telegraph has not announced the response of Boston.
It is not likely to be favorable; but, favorable or not, "Kiting" is still a desperate business, whether unsuccessful in Wall or successful in State street.

The truth is, the Federal Fisc is in a state of collapse.
Without revenue, without funds, without a Treasury, what is Government?
what, especially, is Lincoln's Government?
When the Yankees find that their grand Government won't bleed, that it is in the condition of a turnip and can't bleed, what will become of the much-boasted "loyalty" of the Yankee nation?
Gone glimmering through the dream of things that were;
A school boy's tale; the wonder of an hour.

In fact, the Lincoln Government is this day bankrupt.
Its finances are hopeless.
Its case is beyond treatment.
There is no possibility of its getting along except by direct taxation; and direct taxation destroys any Administration that imposes it at the first popular election; destroys the Federal Government itself in five years.

The exports of the North in time of peace, over and above the gold of California, and the cost of the raw material of their manufactures, is less than fifty millions.
This exportation furnishes the measure of their importation; and no tariff, however high, can produce a sufficient revenue from this importation to support the Northern Federal Government.
If the duties were fifty percent., and did not operate to exclude importations at that high rate, the product of the tariff would even then be only twenty-five millions a year; and the ordinary expenses of Lincoln's Government are eighty millions.
All the saleable public lands are disposed of, and the revenue from that source is forever reduced to merely nominal figures.
There is only one resource left — that of direct taxation.
Direct taxation, we repeat, will overthrow any Administration at the first popular election, and in a few years drive every Western and Middle State out of the Yankee Union.

Burke was right when he said, "the Revenue is the Government." There can be no federal Government on this continent that does not derive a revenue ample to support it in power and strength, from sources imperceptible to the popular senses.
The States tax the people directly through the agency of excise officers distributed in every county.
They occupy the field of direct taxation.
For a federal Government, more remote from the people, to attempt to occupy that field also, and to subject the people to the burden and annoyance of a second set of tax-gatherers, is to dig its own grave.

The exports of the South, including what have heretofore gone to the North, exceed four hundred millions of dollars per annum.
This exportation brings back an approximate amount of imports; and four hundred millions of imports furnish a basis of revenue from indirect and insensible taxation sufficient to build up the pillars of Government in any strength and proportions.
There can be no permanent, stable Federal Government on this continent that is not supported by a revenue system based upon large exports.
The Southern Confederate Government is the only one that can exist North of the Gulf of Mexico.
The Northern Federal Government, for the want of such a system of revenue, must very soon go to ruin.
In a few years we shall see the best of its States "ratting" from the Yankee Union, and knocking at the doors of the Confederacy for admission.

With a foreign commerce in free operation; with every port open to its foreign trade; with free egress for exports and free ingress for imports; with all the regular lines of steamers and sail-packets to European ports, running their regular trips; with its commerce unchecked and unimpeded, except what it enjoyed with the South, still, the Northern tariff brings in nothing to the Federal exchequer, and resort is necessary to direct taxation, or else to loans, and the hand to-mouth expedient of "kiting," for funds to meet the ordinary expenditures of Government.

Nature does not abhor a vacuum more devoutly than the Yankee abhors an empty Government Treasury.
It is for the future to show how long the zeal of the Yankees for the Federal Government, its capital and its flag, will last after their discovery of that "skeleton in the closet," an empty Treasury.

div3.head: "a short, sharp War."
div3.p:
This was the favorite plan of the New York press for the subjugation of the South.
The interests of commerce would not permit the war to be long, and therefore they insisted that Richmond and Memphis must be occupied in July, and the 22d of February succeeding be celebrated by the invaders in New Orleans.--This was no doubt a convenient arrangement for New York and the commercial interests; but Manassas has interposed an insuperable obstacle to the execution of that programme.
However "sharp" the war may be, it is impossible now that it shall be "short," unless the invaders give it up altogether.
They must choose between interest and glory.
We apprehend they will soon begin to ascertain that the latter don't pay.

div3.head: Preparations for hanging.
div3.p:
We learn that in addition to the handcuffs brought by the invading army, was a large number of halters for hanging Southern traitors and rebels.
In all probability the New World has never witnessed such scenes of horror as would have witnessed the triumphant entrance of an invading army in Richmond and other portions of the South, nor has the parallel been seen anywhere, except in Paris in the bloodiest era of the Revolution.
These scenes have, for the present, been avoided, but to make their enactment impossible for the future, the South must put forth all its energies and resources of men and means in support of the Government.

div3.head: Col. Kassaw's Regiment.
div3.p:
--We have been urgently requested to publish a list of the killed and wounded of the Battle; Guards and Governor's Guards, attached to Col. Reyshaw's Second South Carolina Regiment.
If any person can furnish us with a list for publication, it will relieve the anxiety of many friends of those companies.

div3.head: Northern and Southern strength.
div3.p: The New York Express, in its comments on Manassas, has the conscience to assert that "the North has not yet begun to put forth its strength, while the South is strained to the utmost."

We have no disposition to underrate the resources of the North, either in men or money.
But the man who can assert that "the North has not yet begun to put forth its strength," must be blind and deaf to all that has transpired in the North since the inauguration of Lincoln. Possibly Mr. Brooks means that the North has a reserve in the military editors of that city, who have husbanded their irresistible strength till it should be needed.
In that event, we confess that Beauregard, Johnston and Lee will have their hands full.
Forney, Greeley, Brooks, Bryant, Raymond, Webb & Co., heading as heavy columns in the field as in the newspapers!
What army could resist such an invasion?

We have no disposition to undervalue the resources of the North in men and money.--But she has made a gigantic effort in the organization and equipment of the late "Grand Army," and left no stone unturned to ensure her success.
She understood perfectly well and thoroughly realized the importance of a great victory in the first general battle, and she neglected no preventive which could ensure that result.
Whatever her other defects, no one denies the forethought, the circumspection and the energy of Northern character, and all these qualities were exercised in a manner corresponding to the magnitude of the interests at stake.
Such an army in point of members, equipments and artillery as she sent into the field has never been seen on this continent, and victory was considered so certain that luxurious bills of fare had been printed for the entertainment of the victors on various points of the route to Richmond.
She had all the Regulars of the army that could be collected for the purpose, marines from the navy and the very flower of her whole volunteer service.
If this is not "beginning" to put forth her "strength," we know not what is.

The assertion of the Express is equally unfounded that "the South is strained to the utmost." On the contrary, the South, which can bring into the field a million of fighting men, defeated the "Grand Army of the Union" at Manassas with only eighteen thousand troops.
That was the whole number actually engaged, and that was enough.
As for arms and ammunition, every battle-field is a manufactory of both for us, as witness the splendid flying artillery and the twenty thousand muskets which Beauregard and Johnston turned out at the shop at Manassas.

div3.head: Their best Army.
div3.p:
One of the Northern journals frankly confesses that the late. "Grand Army" of the Union was made up of the best fighting materials of the North, of the uniformed volunteer regiments of the large cities, who had some acquaintance with military drill, and which it may be added was led and encouraged by the flower of the regular army.
Moreover, we observe in the Washington Star an incidental reference to a body of marines, who had returned to Washington after the battle, with greatly diminished ranks.
It thus appears that Gen.Scott had not only brought the whole disposable regular army of the United States into the battle, but the marines of the Navy, who, it is well known, are among the best infantry soldiers in the world.
Their artillery was mostly United States Regulars, and the guns are among the best in the world.
It is evident enough, then, that it must be sometime before the North, will all diligence, can bring an army into the field as efficient and well equipped as that which has just been routed at Manassas; for soldiers are not made in a day, nor even, as the late rout has demonstrated, in three months.

In the meantime, whilst the North is preparing for another assault, the South will be equally active, and, no longer remaining as a target to be shot at, will assume the offensive and carry the war into the enemy's country.

div3.head: The three months Volunteers.
div3.p:
The New York Herald, of the 22d, says that the number of the three months Northern volunteers whose term of service is about to expire, is eighty thousand.
Those in Virginia, it says, are the best in the service, and "the loss of their aid just now would be nearly irreparable.
Thanks, however, to the good judgment of Gen. McDowell, and the confidence reposed in him, such a misfortune need scarcely be anticipated." What does the Herald think of McDowell's good judgment and "the confidence reposed in him, now?

div3.head: The Danville Railroad.
div3.p:
A highly respectable correspondent of Halifax complains that the Danville Railroad charges freight on every box and package contributed for the comfort and aid of the soldiers, and the sick and wounded.
We believe the roads generally have allowed those gifts of the patriotic and philanthropic to pass untaxed, and we think very properly.--We suppose that the Danville road, if it has not already done so, will readily conform to a custom so considerate.
There are none more true to the cause than the entire company — officers, stockholders and all.

div3.head: Aid and comfort for the wounded.
div3.p:
--The New Orleans Picayune, of the 28th ult., notices the departure from that city for Virginia, of a party of ladies, who propose to establish a free hospital in Richmond for the wounded braves of our noble army.
These philanthropic and patriotic ladies forsake the comforts and ease of their homes to bestow upon the sick and wounded that soothing care and consolation which alone can emanate from the soothing hand of woman.

Another party of ladies in the same city have entered upon a similar mission, consisting of Mrs. Bell, who has three sons in our army; Mrs. Lenhart, whose husband is also in the field; Mrs. Spooner, who has a son in the ranks, and Mrs. Walker, who has many relatives and friends engaged in our glorious cause.
These ladies will be accompanied by two experienced surgeons.
All honor to the ladies of New Orleans.

div3.head: Camp Hodges.
div3.p:
--A letter from Camp Hodges, on James River, gives a favorable account of affairs at that post.
The troops have perfect confidence in their commander--Col. D. J. Godwin, late of Portsmouth — and both officers and men are enjoying excellent health.
Attached to Col. Godwin's command is the Henrico Artillery, Captain J. H. Sands, who has also the immediate command of the water batteries.
Captain S. is regarded there as an able and efficient officer.
Active preparations are progressing on the Peninsula for an engagement with the enemy.

div3.head: Army houses.
div3.p:
--A correspondent informs us that there are now in stable at Louisa Court-House, ten horses, presented to the State of Virginia by citizens of that county.
The expenses of keeping them there amount to seven dollars per day. It really seems to be the duty of the authorities to send for these animals, especially since they are needed for the service, and the people of Louisa are somewhat mortified to see their gifts treated in this way. We hope the matter will be attended to.

div3.head: Routrees Stocks
div3.p: --The following were the quotations at the New York Stock Board July 29: Virginia 8's, 49; Missouri 6's, 41 a 41 ½ Tennessee bonds, 47; North Carolina bonds, 81

div3.head: The late Homicide followed by an attempt at murder!
div3.p:
--Yesterday we learned that young Davis, who shot Capt. Axson on the Wilmington cars on Tuesday evening, was taken by a mob from a car on the south side of the river, opposite the city, and after being conveyed some half a mile or so, was shot and stabbed several times.
Though not killed outright, it is feared that his wounds are mortal.
Some account of this shocking affair will be found in our local column, and it is also referred to in a letter, which we publish below.

We published yesterday an account of the killing of Capt. Axson, which was furnished by members of his company.
We regret that in it the paper was led into the statement of circumstances that certainly reflect upon Mr. Davis, and are disputed.
We are satisfied that he was a gentleman most respectably connected, and held in warm esteem amongst his fellow-citizens.
We give place very readily to the following communication in his vindication:

div4.p:
--In your issue of this morning, under the heading of "Lamentable Affairs," I find an account of the shooting of Captain Axson, 1st South Carolina Volunteers, by Mr. Davis, of 2d Georgia Volunteers.
So far as the fact of Captain Axson having been shot by Mr. Davis you are correct, and in so far only.
From disinterested eye-witnesses, (witnesses who do not belong to either State, South Carolina or Georgia,) I learn that both parties were inebriated; that Mr. Davis did cut one, or perhaps more, melons of Captain Axson's; when taxed for so doing Mr. Davis apologized, stating that he had supposed they were for sale, (as fruit was thus exposed all along the line,) and that he expected to pay for them on the appearance of the owner; that he was sorry for the mistake; that the excuse satisfied Captain A., when both drank together, more than once. A dispute afterwards arose, during which Captain Axson held Mr. Davis to the floor, choking him. On being released Mr. Davis left the car, and procuring his side-arms returned to the car and to his seat, remarking that he would not suffer himself to be thus imposed on again; that on Captain Axson's making a rush on him, Mr. Davis shot him. Your informant neglected to state to you other facts: that Major Butt, of the Second Georgia Regiment immediately arrested Mr. D., disarmed him and conveyed him to this city; that he left him in one of the cars, under a corporal's guard, and went to hunt up the proper authorities, to whom he intended to surrender him; that during his absence the guard was set upon by a posse of armed men, (supposed to belong to Capt Axson's company;) that being no longer able to hold him the guard surrendered him, on the posse or mob promising to only convey him to the proper authorities; that that armed mob took Mr. Davis a half mile out of town, and there brutally murdered him; shooting him, and on his falling, one of the party ran up and stabbed him. Mr. Davis was totally unarmed at the time, Major Butt having taken his arms from him. Had he had them about him, no such a cowardly assassination would have been attempted; for men who could thus act, would have lacked the courage to have attacked him openly, when armed.
Mr. Davis is well known in Georgia; his previous character has been unimpeachable.
His conduct at home and abroad has been that of the true gentleman. The blood of Georgia's Governors flow not in other veins, and the 2d Georgia Regiment had hoped that the press of Richmond would have waited until a judicial investigation had thrown full light on the affair.
I do not know why the disposition of the fruit being brought by Capt. A. was mentioned.
The piece says it was for "distinguished friends in Richmond." If, by its mention, it was intended to leave the impression of social inequality on the part of Mr. D., it should have been left out; for Mr. D, socially, was any one's equal.
He occupied in his native State a high social position, and deservedly.
He was connected with (and never disgraced his connection,) the most honorable families in Georgia, being a grandson of ex-Gov. Schley.
So much for "distinguished friends" and its inference.

div3.head: Useful military Works.
div3.p:
--J. W. Randolph, the publisher, has laid upon our table three very useful hand-books for the camp and the field.
They are as follows:

q.p: "Directions for Cooking by Troops in Camp and Hospital. Prepared for the Army of Virginia, and published by order of the Surgeon General; with essays on taking food and what food, by Florence Nightingale." This is very timely, and contains highly valuable instructions for the present exigencies in camp and hospital.

Instructions for Officers and Non-Commissioned Officers of Cavalry on Outpost Duty--By Lieut. Col. Von Arentschildt, First Hussars, King's German Legion: with an abridgment of them by Lieutenant Colonel the Hon. F. Ponsonby, Twelfth Light Dragoons, British Army."
"The Hand-Book of Artillery. By Captain Jos. Roberts, Fourth Regiment Artillery' United States Army."

These are all small and convenient hand-books, and are from the best authorities on their several subjects.
For sale by J. W. Randolph.

div3.head: The first Massachusetts Regiment.
div3.p:
--This is the regiment that was rendered notorious by a double-quick march through Baltimore on the 19th of April. Great things were expected of these heroes in the late encounters, and when the first advance was made upon Bull Run, they were so posted as to have an opportunity of meeting the South Carolinians, whom they had singled out as especial objects of hatred.
All we can learn in regard to the result is, that of the whole of the troops engaged the First Massachusetts suffered the heaviest loss, and that when the battle raged the hottest, "they broke ranks, and, scattering in different directions, continued their hasty retreat for some distance through the woods." The Massachusetts fugitives could not be rallied.

div3.head: Bureau of Hospital supplies.
div3.p:
--A "Central Bureau," for the collection and distribution of hospital supplies from South Carolina has been established at Charlottesville, Va., Persons coming on with stores from South Carolina are requested to carry them there, and those wishing to proffer their aid or that of nurses can report there.
Any one wishing information concerning the sick, or the best mode of relieving them, can obtain it by applying in person, at their residence, or by letter, to any of the following named gentlemen in Charlottesville: Rev. R. W. Barnwell, Jr., Mr. Wm. C. Bee, Mr. George M. Coffin, and Dr. M. LaBorde, of South Carolina.

div3.head: Death of a young soldier.
div3.p:
--A son of Col. Gartrell, of one of the Georgia Regiments, who was severely wounded in the late battle, died at the residence of Rice W. Payne, Esq., in Warrenton, Va., on Sunday last, and was buried with military honors.
He was but 17 years of age. It will be consoling to his friends to know that every attention was bestowed upon him by the benevolent family with whom he sojourned.

div3.head: A faithful negro.
div3.p:
--An apparently trifling but amusing incident which took place recently in the neighborhood of Charleston, is fraught with no small degree of admiration and instruction to the abolition vandals of the North.
Doubtless, not the least auxiliary to the accomplishment of their wicked and diabolical purposes in the inroads upon our country on which they relied, was the hope and expectation of disaffecting our slave population, if not indeed the actual incorporation of this class of persons in their armies.
The following colloquium is calculated to instruct them on the subject:

A negro man of T. P. Pendleton, Esq., residing in Clarke county, when out on his master's business, was met by one of these monsters in human shape, who immediately entered upon the plan of bringing over the slave to his views and duds.
Trying first persuasive means and finding them ineffectual, he resorted to threats, and told the negro that he would capture and arrest him. To this the servant, with characteristic faith in his master's authority, replied "You better let me alone; I win on my master's business, and I bound you catch it if you meddle with me."
Herman Cos. a prominent lawyer, died in Nashville, Tenn., last Monday.

opener.salute: To the Editor of the Dispatch:

div4.p: --Among the many incidents of the battle of Manassas which have been reported in the city press since the fight, there was one important fact which should not be passed over in silence, and I am surprised that it has not before this time been mentioned, viz: the share which two South Carolina regiments had in the affair.

These regiments (the 2d South Carolina, Col. Kershaw, and the 3d South Carolina, Col. Cash,) reached the scene of action about 1½ o'clock P. M. Just before they caught sight of the enemy, they were met by at least fifteen hundred of our men — many of them wounded — coming away from the field of battle, who told them "the day was lost!" that "we could do nothing with the enemy, for their artillery was too strong for us!" that "Col. Hampton and all his officers were killed, and the enemy were driving our forces back!" This was the tenor of the information received by these two Palmetto regiments, who had already gone over four miles of hilly and broken ground at the double-quick step, and were, of course, in no plight to plunge into a contest with twenty times their force, probably flushed with the prospect of victory, and excited to madness by the contest.
But, the gallant Palmettos, although believing they were marching on to certain destruction — upon a worse than forlorn hope — never faltered a moment, except to inquire the nearest way to the scene of combat, and hurried on. They soon heard a sharp volley from a wood in front, and the balls whistled through their ranks, cutting down many of their number, while the air overhead was alive with the hoarse scream of shells and the hum of cannon shot, as they crashed through the branches around.

Charging through the wood, they came in sight of the enemy — the N. Y. Fire Zouaves and the Chasseurs — and with a cheer that was heard above the din of battle, rushed upon the foe, firing as they went!
The enemy immediately broke and fled across fields, fences and ditches for about a mile; but five or six regiments of them rallied on a high hill opposite.
The Palmettos made at them, but were ordered to halt.
Why this order was given we could not at first see, for our ranks were being rapidly thinned by the long-range Minnie and Maynard guns of the Yankees.
But while asking each other what it meant, we heard the clear voice of Col. Kershaw ringing over the field, "Boys, He down and let the artillery fire over you!"--We immediately fell upon our faces, and the artillery (consisting of two pieces of Kemper's Alexandria Battery,) sent death and desolation among the well drawn up lines of the foe on the opposite hill, while our men picked off the officers or individuals occupying prominent places among them.
They began to waver, and a few more shots from Kemper and a volley or two between the pauses of the artillery from the deadly Mississippi rifles of the Palmetto boys completed the rout, and the enemy fled in confusion.
Their own artillery, (six splendid rifled pieces of Griffin's Battery) was turned upon them, and lent additional terror to their flight.
But the fact to which I referred in the beginning of this slight outline was this:--These two South Carolina regiments, together with Kemper's Battery and a detachment of the Va.
Black Horse Cavalry, pursued the enemy for six miles beyond the field of battle and captured over twenty pieces of artillery, besides arms and stores innumerable, which otherwise would have been carried off!

div3.head:
[for the Richmond Dispatch.]
Hospital supplies.
div3.p:
The Managers of this Depository respectfully ask of those sending supplies by Express to see they are "pre-paid," or some arrangement made with the Express company in advance.
Packages from a distance, not unfrequently arrive with a bill of charges on them almost amounting to a purchase.
Our railroad companies kindly transport supplies free, but by some mismanagement they frequently miscarry.
The attention of agents on the road is earnestly asked to this.
It is with pleasure the ladies can say to the contributors to the Depository, that several thousands of our brave and gallant soldiers have received aid at their hands, suited to their several wants as sick, wounded and hungry, and in many cases such necessaries as could not otherwise have been obtained. "Flaxseed meal," for poultices, is very much wanted.

div3.head: The people of Richmond.
div3.p: --The following, from the Montgomery Confederation, shows that the exertions of our inhabitants, in behalf of the wounded soldiers, are appreciated by those at a distance:

In the excitement of the battle, during the agony of distress of many a father and relative, while the poor mother was weeping over the dead body of her son who had fallen a martyr in his country's cause, the kind, generous-hearted, liberal people of the city of Richmond were not idle spectators of the passing events.
So soon as the war note was sounded — so soon as the battle commenced, to the time when the conflict ended, anticipating our victory, yet looking for a heavy loss on our side, the good people of this city gave notice to their Mayor that their houses were open to the killed, wounded and sick.
A committee was appointed to collect the money which was being profusely tendered by her citizens for the benefit of the poor unfortunate ones who fell in the battle, while another one was appointed to go to Manassas and bring them to that city for the purpose of having them properly attended to. This was, as our telegraphic correspondent has truthfully said, a god-like kindness indeed.
Let us not forget Richmond or her good people.

div3.head: The English press on Lincoln's Message.
div3.p: A telegraphic summary of the news by the Africa contains the following:

q.p:
The English journals all criticise the message of President Lincoln.
The Times says it altogether confirms the impression produced by his first message.
He has outweighed all the chances of internecine war, and as a bystander, the editor thinks that the recognition of Southern independence is the issue in which, after infinite loss and humiliation, the contest must result.

The London Pilot says--"At this date it is idle to argue on the question of legal rights; it is for the Government to put down resistance as soon as possible." It predicts "an obstinate and sanguinary struggle," and while professing personal hostility to slavery, rejoices at England's neutrality.
The Daily News eulogizes the message, and says it sets at rest the question of compromise, and that the Government is now in a position to secure, by energetic action, the sympathy of foreign powers.
The Telegraph and Star quarrel with the message, and say it is very unsatisfactory.

div3.head: Counting the cost.
div3.p: --The Bridgeport (Conn.) Farmer says:

q.p:
Some mathematician who believes in going into small particulars, states that the cost of the Chicago Platform civil war now going on is over $60,000 per hour; $1,000 per minute; or about $17 per second.
These are nice little sums for tax-payers to dwell upon.

div3.head: Quick time
div3.p: --An editor in Washington says:"We are indebted to a gentleman direct from Bull Run, for important information in advance of the army!"

div3.head: Important to Travelers.
div3.p: --The shortest and quickest route from Manassas to Washington — the road the Federals took.
Ex-President Van Buren is reported to have said on the 15th of July, that the war ought to be vigorously prosecuted until the full authority of the United States Government is re-established.
Private Charles H. Walker, of the Governor's Guard, 3d Georgia Regiment, died in Portsmouth on Monday of typhoid fever.
A son of Daniel J. Turner, of Portsmouth, Va., was drowned last Tuesday, near South Mills, N. C.

It is said that Charles Mathews and his wife are not living happily together.
If so, its no wonder.
The Rev. James M. Russell, of Dadeville, Tallapoosa county, Ala., is raising a company of mounted guerillas for the war.

div3.head: Tragic affair.
div3.p:
--The Dispatch contained yesterday an account of the shooting of Capt. Charles H. Axson, of Company "M," 1st Regiment South Carolina Volunteers, on Tuesday evening, near Wilson, N. C., on the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, by Arthur B. Davis, of the Second Georgia Regiment, then en route for this city.
The perpetrator of the act was put under guard for conveyance to this city and trial by martial law.

The circumstances attending the death of Capt. Axson, excited a feeling of bitter indignation against Davis, though no attempt at retaliation was indulged in prior to the arrival of the Petersburg cars on Wednesday evening. When they reached the depot in this city, four South Carolina volunteers approached the car in which the prisoner was confined under guard, and expressed an intention of shooting him. Finding them determined, the superintendent of the road (Thos. H. Wynn, Esq.,) ordered the car containing the prisoner and guard (two men armed with muskets) to be backed to the Manchester side of the river.
This was done, and the four who had made the demonstration, being told that Davis would be carried across the river to the camp near the reservoir, left in the latter direction.
It appears, however, that there were others present bent on the same errand of vengeance.
The bridge guard says five or six soldiers passed him and would not be repulsed when he ordered them to return.
The result of sending Davis across the bridge, in company with two men as guard ignorant of their duty, is found in the following narrative furnished us by a member of the regiment to which he was attached.
Our informant says:

q.p:
Davis, upon arriving in Richmond, was left by Major Butts in care of a guard of the Belfair Volunteers, Captain Smith.
He ordered the car to be backed across the river, and proceeded to the camp to report to Col. Semmes.
Very shortly afterwards a party of men, supposed to belong to Captain Axson's company, came and asked him from the guard, promising, on the faith of gentlemen, that he should be delivered to the proper authorities.
Assured by them, he followed them.
On the road they attempted to borrow a rope.
When they got to a ravine they halted, and told him they were going to hand him. He protested against it, and said that they had pledged their faith to him. One stepped in front of him, saying "faith, be d — d; I am going to shoot you," and upon that shot him. Davis then turned to escape; they rushed upon him, and cut at him with bowie-knives, inflicting several wounds.
Davis fell, partially insensible.
Again, while on the ground, they inflicted a wound with a knife in the neck, and one on the head.
Supposing him dead, they turned to leave, when one of them asked if they had better not send for a doctor.
He was answered by one who said "No; if he is not dead, let's finish him;" and approaching him, fired at him within a few feet.
The ball did not take effect.
He now lies critically ill at the residence of Dr. F. E. Luckett, of Manchester.
The ball, which may prove fatal, passed between the first rib and clavicle, and glancing downwards, imbedded itself in the deep tissues of the back under the shoulder-blade, from whence it was removed yesterday morning.--The knife wounds, though very bad, are not in themselves fatal.
Three more men returned after the affair, and inquired if he was dead, and on being told no, but mortally wounded, laughed and went off.

Before being removed to Dr. Luckett's house, Davis, supposing himself dying, asked permission to make a declaration before the proper authorities.
He was taken to the Town Hall, and his evidence stands recorded by a magistrate.
The circumstances of the shooting and stabbing are gathered from Mr. Davis' statements.

div3.head: The female Hessian and her Companion.
div3.p:
--Capt. Fremaux and Wm. S. Read, of the 8th Louisiana Regiment, arrived, on Wednesday evening, with the first female prisoner, a Mrs. Curtis, who was captured at Fall's Church on Sunday last, dressed in military clothes.
She belongs, it appears, to the 2d N. Y. Regiment.
The woman was on horseback at the time.

Under the head of "Picked Up," the Black Republican papers say, in giving an account of the above transaction, that on Saturday last a member of the New York 13th Regiment was riding out on horseback with Mrs. Curtis, (who is from Rochester, and has a brother in the Abolition army,) and another lady, near Bailey's Cross-Roads.
They ventured too far, and were surrounded by a squad of patriot cavalry, who seized the unhappy Lincolnite, but offered to let his comrades go. Mrs. C. preferring, as she said, to await the arrival of some of her Black Republican companions, the officer in charge of our men thought it best to bring her along, and did so.
The person brought with her to this city is named Wm. Edw. Taylor, a Virginian, of rather seedy appearance, who was taken up on Monday on suspicion of being a spy.

div3.head: Complimentary.
div3.p:
--The New York Express pays a high but deserved compliment to the ladies of the South, when it says that "it pains them to reflect that the most impulsive, perhaps the most infuriated parties to this war, are many of the women of the South.
All along they have been among the leading Secessionists, particularly so in South Carolina and Virginia.
There have been marked exceptions, perhaps; but they have been like the angel's visits, few and far between."

The editor, and his brother "Hessians," will find, as this war progresses, that the race of the noble dames is by no means extinct.
Patriotism and love of right over wrong and oppression is instinctive with women, while with such creatures as the writer of the Express, patriotism is controlled and directed by interest.
For instance, when it recommended him to Southern homes and hearts, Brooks was, or pretended to be, a national man. His interests being in jeopardy, he joins the foul pack of hounds running at the heels of Abe Lincoln, and none excel him in crying "havoc — let slip the dogs of war." Anything that he may think lamentable in the conduct of Southern ladies, the latter will of course consider in the light of a compliment.
