div3.head: The wounded Hessians.
div3.p:
--There are several hundred wounded Abolition soldiers now in this city receiving medical treatment, the majority of whom are at the general Hospital, North corner of 2d street. It has been found necessary to establish another Hospital for their use in Ross' factory, Main street, nearly opposite the prison depot.
Sick Hessians, while receiving every care and attention at our hands, are attended by seven of their own surgeons.

div3.head: Hessian guns.
div3.p:
--We saw yesterday about 1,800 of the guns taken from the Hessians at Manassas, in the recent battle, which had been brought to this city to clean up and fix for use. About 10,000 more were expected to arrive.
Nearly all of those we saw were loaded, not having been discharged (in the usual way) by their former owners.
Some of the muskets bore evidence of the hard usage which they had received.

div3.head: Bank arrangement.
div3.p: --The Banks in Richmond, and those in Savannah, including the branches of each, have made arrangements by which their notes will be received by each other at per.
Volunteers and others may go directly to the Banks, and get the full value of their money.

div3.head: Notice to the Curious.
div3.p:
--Citizens are not allowed to visit Bull Run or Manassas, under any pretext.
This is from headquarters.--Parties with mere curiosity than discretion will do well to remember it.

div3.head: Mayor's Court.
div3.p:
--The attention of law-breakers being absorbed at present by matters of more import than the manufacture of subjects for critical dissertation at the hands of the local, the latter for several days past has been forced to convert his usual record into a miscellaneous jumble of causes and effects.
No improvement was noticed yesterday.
The cases were few and of a trifling character.--The following is a list: Pat. Gheelan, arrested for assaulting an unknown man, was acquitted, complainant not appearing; A. Rehm, arraigned as a general disturber of the peace, was required to give $200 surety for his good behavior; Denis Kersey and Robert Kane, for disorderly conduct, and Michael Brannon, for drunkenness, were admonished and discharged; Seaton Anderson, free, charged with stealing a pair of boots worth $5 from Cosby Ricks, was converted into an operative on city defences; James McDonald was fined $15 for keeping his bar- room open after 10 o'clock at night on the 27th inst.

div3.head: Outrageous conduct.
div3.p:
--The soldiers encamped near Hollywood Cemetery are admonished most earnestly against firing towards the burying-ground.
On yesterday, while a minister was officiating at a grave surrounded by a group of persons, a spent ball from a pistol, fired outside of the enclosure, reached the party and struck the undertaker's deputy in the back.
It fell to the ground without perforating his coat, and was picked up by him; but a little more force, or a little nearer position, would have produced a result so shocking that the bare contemplation of it is enough to demand the serious attention of officers and soldiers to guard them against such occurrences in future.

div3.head: Alderman Hill.
div3.p:
--We regret to chronicle this morning the death of Charles B. Hill, Esq., one of the Justices of the Hustings Court of this city.
The rumor of his dangerous illness was mentioned a few days since.
By his death the city loses a valuable public servant, the South a man ardently devoted to its rights, his friends (and they were many and warmly attached) one who could always be counted on in the hour of need, his family and relatives one whose summons hence will prove a source of deep and lasting affliction to them.
Peace to his ashes.

div3.head: The weather.
div3.p:
--Wednesday was one of the most oppressive days of the season.
The sun's vertical rays were of such an ardent kind that no doubt was left on the mind of his intention to prove the existence of the "dog days." Yesterday a change in the existing order of things took place.
The sky, during the morning, was overcast with clouds, betokening rain, which fell from about 11 o'clock continually for several hours.

div3.head: The box
div3.p:
which has attracted so much attention at the Central Depot, was opened yesterday and found to contain only an empty burial case.
Our informant, who smelt something offensive, may have had his imagination wrought upon by the sight of blood-stained letters lying all about.
There certainly was no corpse in the box.

div3.head: More wounded prisoners.
div3.p:
--The Central train last night brought in upward of 70 prisoners, all wounded in the recent battle at Manassas.
Some of them were modest enough to declare that the South was in the right in this contest, and that it would take more than Lincoln's 400,000 to subjugate a nation of such men as fought at Manassas.

div3.head: Serious accident.
div3.p: --We regret to learn that a little child of Mr. J. Bacharah was seriously injured yesterday afternoon by falling from the porch to the pavement, a distance of ten or fifteen feet. Dr. Jackson was promptly in attendance and rendered all necessary aid to the little sufferer, so seriously injured.

div3.head: Expected.
div3.p: --The Calhoun Artillery--six rifled Parrott guns, fifty horses, and ninety men — were expected in Richmond yesterday, via the Petersburg Railroad.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p: --Rev. Dr. Hoge and family, New York; Capt. Rosscau, C. S. N.; H. A. Deas, Mobile; R. F. Pinckney, C. S. N., and others, arrived in Richmond yesterday.

div3.head: Contribution.
div3.p: --The generous sum of $100, left at this office yesterday by Mr. E. H. Craige, for the benefit of the sick and wounded, has been handed over to the committee.

div3.head: Returned home.
div3.p: --Mr. Wm. F. Ritchie, State Printer, who left the city several months since on a visit to France, returned a few days since.

div3.head: North Carolina Volunteers.
div3.p: --Seven or eight companies of a North Carolina Regiment of State Troops arrived in this city yesterday, and went into camp below this city.

div4.p: We continue our summary of war matters, from newspapers lately received:

div4.head: Evacuation of Harper's Ferry.
div4.p:
It appears from one of the Black Republican telegrams that the entire force under Gen. Banks crossed the Potomac to the Maryland ble on the 28th of July, except the 2d Massachusetts Regiment, which remained at the Ferry as a guard.
The reason alleged for this movement is the indefensible character of the place.
We place but little confidence in Northern reports, and this one may or may not be true.
The Baltimore Exchange mentions a rumor that Gen. Banks will proceed to erect a battery upon "Eagle Rock," a high bluff opposite Berlin, which will command the railroad for several miles either way.--His headquarters for the present are on a hill in the rear of Sandy Hook, on the Maryland side.
It is believed by some that the Ferry has been entirely evacuated.
The Washington correspondent of the Exchange writes.

The opinion prevails that the evacuation of Harper's Ferry was made in the face of, or in anticipation of, an offensive demonstration of the Confederate forces in the vicinity of Winchester and Charlestown.

Messrs. Blair and Chase have implicit confidence in General Banks, and they regard the backward movement from Harper's Ferry as most probably a matter of necessity.
On the contrary.
Messrs. Cameron and Scott deem Banks a hasty and unreliable commander, and its primary movement of the civilian General is looked upon as decidedly an over one.

The reports of Gen. Patterson fully satisfies Gen. Scott that the army of the former was ly inefficient, and that no movement he could have made would have retarded the movements of Gen. Johnston, short of a battle, in which the forces of Patterson would have suffered severely and perhaps sustained an unanimous rout.

Orders have gone forth that will in a few days cause the deficiency in the army of the Shenandoah to be filled by new recruits — Neither Gens. Patterson nor Cadwalader will offer their services again, but will serve if they are called upon in an exigency.

Gen. Scott will soon cause the lines of the army on the other side of the Potomac river to be slowly extended.
An attempt will be made to re-occupy Fairfax Court-House, if it can be done without a general engagement.

div4.head: From Fortress Monroe.
div4.p:
We have already published an account of the burning of a considerable portion of the town of Hampton, by the Hessians.
It appears from the Northern accounts that this act of vandalism was perpetrated in apprehension of an attack by the Confederates.
The Federal troops were entirely withdrawn from the place.
Part of Hampton bridge was destroyed to prevent communication with Fortress Monroe.
The account goes on to say:

q.p:
Capt. Bryan, of the Georgia Hussars, and four others, came in yesterday with the flag of truce relative to the baggage of Captain Jenkins and artist Shurtliff, who were wounded and made prisoners by the Secessionists some time ago. It turns out that they were me by a party of amateur soldiers on the other side.
The flag was received by Captain Butler and Lieutenant Wiegel outside the entrenchments.
A proposal to exchange them for the Confederate soldiers was rejected, but arrangements were made to forward the baggage of the wounded men. The flag of truce was doubtless a feint for reconnoitering Hampton and the vicinity.

A flag of truce came into Newport News this morning with a proposition giving our troops twenty-four hours to leave, and announcing that in case the place is not vacated they will force us out. The gunboat Dale, of twenty guns, at once went up from Old Point.
The Albatros and Penguin are also stationed there, while the Minnesota and seven gunboats at Old Point are ready to assist should Newport News really be attacked.
Colonel Phelps says he can hold the place against twice his force, which now consists of four effective regiments.
The entrenchments are of a formidable character, and the Confederates will meet a warm reception.
But flags of truce of course represent that there is a very large Confederate force between Yorktown and Old Point.

div4.head: Gallantry of Alexandria troops.
div4.p: The Alexandria correspondent of the Baltimore Exchange writes, July, 29 as follows:

The conduct of the Alexandria boys in both battles is spoken of in the highest terms; and the charge of the Alexandria Riflemen, led on by Capt. Morton Marye, in the Thursday's fight, is said to have been one of the most gallant and splendid military manœuvres ever witnessed.
Most nobly did that little band of as true hearts as ever fluttered, advance upon the foe, and bearing down all before them, lead the way to a quick and glorious triumph.
The Old Dominion Rifles, not a whit behind their fathers and brothers (who were in the foremost company) in courage, discipline, and all that goes to make a true soldier, were in the thickest of this hard fought battle.
They were led on by Captain Arthur Herbert, than whom a nobler or braver does not exist.
It is said that the Old Dominion Rifles, in crossing the bridge and charging the enemy, did so with a yell and huzza that completely bewildered the Ohio regiment opposing them, and that their charge was a perfect success.
In this battle one of Alexandria's bravest sons fell, and in his fall this whole community is sunk in sadness.
Those Sangster, son of Edward Sangster, lately the Sheriff of this county, fell pierced by a ball.
He was generally known, and by all who knew him, beloved.
For an entire absence from anything like fear he was remarkable from a child.
He was as kind as brave.
He died in a noble cause, and his memory is enshrined, along with all who fell there, in the hearts of a brave and generous nation.

Our people are also called upon to mourn the death of Henry Clay Ward, who, though not properly speaking one of "our boys," yet from his long residence here before he removed to his native town, Warrenton, was well known and highly esteemed.
Kind hearted and generous, of a most happy disposition, Clay was a great favorite, especially among the ladies, and his death in the prime of life, at the hands of a Northern foe, is most warmly felt.
He died a soldier's death, fighting for all that is held sacred by a true friend of Virginia.
May be rest in peace!--Lieutenant Ward was first Lieutenant in Captain Murray's Warrenton Rifles.

The exploits of the Alexandria Artillery, "Red Devils," as the returned Zouaves call them, are said to have been wonderful.
Seen in all parts of the field, in the battle of Sunday, they managed their pieces with a celerity and dexterity that astonished their enemies and elicited the highest encomiums from even Beauregard himself, who is not much given to compliments.
In the pursuit of the routed hirelings this company of artillery were foremost, and did not stop until overcome by fatigue.
Many of them fell on the road-side, exhausted.

Correspondents of the Exchange write that Mrs. W. Greenwood, Mary Murphy and Mr. Archibald Wilkinson have been murdered lately in Alexandria by some of Lincoln's demons.
Such occurrences are very common there.
Gen. McCall has superseded Gen. Kenyan in command at Alexandria.
It appears that there is some apprehension of a "rising" of the inhabitants, and two pieces of cannon have been posted upon Shuter's Hill, sweep the town in such an event.
A letter from Alexandria says:

q.p:
The statement of the Associated Press in regard to the intelligence brought from Manassas Station by Mr. Birch, is totally different from the statements made in this city yesterday by that gentleman.
He stated here that up to the time he left, the Confederates had buried nearly 10,000 of the Federal dead, killed at Bull's Run, and that the force of the Proposal Marshal, 500 in number, had been engaged for a week in the burial of these unfortunate men, and had not yet finished the work. This but confirms the statement of a reliable gentleman who reached here 'on Thursday last, and stated that up to that time 7,300 of the Federal dead had been buried.

div4.head: Rigid discipline.
div4.p: One of the unreliable dispatches from Washington says:

q.p:
the entrance of Gen. McClellan upon his duties as commander of this Military department, has inspired the troops in and around Washington with renewed military enthusiasm.
He has already visited the various entrenchments on the Virginia side, thoroughly examining into their condition and strength, and has instituted the strictest discipline among the soldiers and in all the departments of the service within his jurisdiction.

Brigadier, regimental and civil officers are made to understand that lounging and tippling around the camps are not to be permitted.
The much abused passport system has been greatly restricted, and the facilities heretofore enjoyed so freely of communication between Washington and the rebellious States have seen as far as practicable curtailed.
The effect of his vigorous measures generally where fell, and the army has begun to realize the presence of a military power which may be safely trusted.

div4.head: Ing and Shouting.
div4.p: The members of the th New York Regiment have been arrested at Alexandria for burning the buildings known as Rocks's Mills,

on the Loudoun and Hampshire Railroad.
A member of the 24th New York was killed by one of his own regiment while robbing a potatoes patch.
The "secession residents" are reported to be boldly tampering with the soldiers.

div4.head: The blockade question.
div4.p:
The Northern papers give a very important aspect to the blockade question.
It appears that an official communication on the subject has been made to the Federal Government by Admiral Milne, commanding the large British fleet--now numbering thirty-five vessels of war — in the Gulf of Mexico.
By what means the purport of this document has found its way to the public eye, it is, perhaps, needless to inquire; the fact that it should have been suffered to see the light gives it, in our opinion, the aspect of an indirect warning addressed by the British Government.

The British commander, whose opinion is backed by the observations and reports of the commanders of his thirty-five vessels-of-war, says, with emphasis, that the attempt of the Federal Government to close the seceded ports has been characterized by a "complete absence of uniformity, order and regularity!"

The Admiral proceeds to enumerate the number of breaches of the blockade which have come under his notice.
Though Pensacola was declared closed on the 19th of May, "vessels freely obtained admission" as late as the 30th.
A bark warned off from Pensacola ran into Mobile.
Twenty or thirty small vessels ran into other neighboring ports, and he finds "numerous cases of ships, barks and brigs escaping the cruisers" in every direction.
As for Charleston, "a complete flotilla of small ocean traders and coasters had continued to pass into the city and out again, regardless of, or insensible to, the presence of war ships." "St. Marks, in Florida, an important port, is not at all cut off from the maritime trade." "Steamers keep up communication to and from Savannah;" and his captains report four other ports entirely open on the very day he writes.

From this report of the Admiral, which distinctly takes the ground that the blockade is inefficient, there is good reason for supposing that we shall see a prompt and decided attitude assumed by Great Britain, France and Spain, at an early day.

The Prime Minister of Great Britain said, in his remarks in Parliament, that this Government would respect an efficient blockade.
This was the same thing as though he had said it would not respect an inefficient one.

div4.head: Signs of Reaction.
div4.p: The following is an extract from a letter from Carlisle, Pa., written some days after the battle:

q.p:
At last this community has awakened to a proper appreciation of the enormities of the conduct of the present Administration.
From the time President Lincoln issued his first proclamation for troops up to within a few days, it was almost worth a man's life to express dissent to his policy.
Men who for years have been battling against the pernicious doctrines of the Republican party and in defence of constitutional rights, have been marked by the eager adherents of the Administration, and watched, in hopes that they would indulge in some expression which would be an excuse for hounding on the Government mercenaries.

Now, however, things have assumed a new phase.
The already enormous expenditures by the Government, and the still more enormous ones which are threatened, have opened the eyes of the people and placed before them the consequences which must inevitably ensue from a continuation of this struggle.
The threatened direct tax bill has gone directly to their hearts before it has reached their pockets; and men who were most clamorous for this war are now desirous of a speedy termination of the difficulty.
It is no longer a crime to criticise the action of the Government and condemn a policy which, if carried out, will saddle on the people an enormous national debt.
The agricultural portion of the community, convinced that in the end it will have the burdens to bear, is loudest in its disapprobation; and many of those who ten days ago were finding fault with the Government for not prosecuting the war with more vigor, are now earnest in their demands for an honorable peace.

It is not alone the financial view of this question which has caused this change.
The recent battle at Bull Run has convinced the people that the conquest of the South is not to be a holiday pastime, but a death struggle.
The people here have been woefully deceived in relation to the condition of affairs in the South.
The politicians have labored to impress the people with the belief that there was no unanimity in the South, and that as soon as the Federal troops entered Virginia an immense Union sentiment would welcome them.
Instead of which they have been met by bayonets and disastrously routed.

div4.p: A prominent citizen of Philadelphia writes to a gentleman of Baltimore, ( July 27,) as follows:

q.p:
My views on this war are unchanged, and coincide with those of the brave Breckinridge of Kentucky.
I know, and am finding every day, that they are the views of thousands of those of our fellow freemen of the North.
I tell you, that the opposition to this war is on the increase, and has arrayed on its side thousands and tens of thousands of the influential citizens of the misled portion of our unhappy country.
There are numerous Marylanders in this city, and Northern Breckinridge Democrats, who are proud and tenacious of their opinions, which it is almost counted treason to utter, and who sympathize deeply with the South in their efforts to repel the invaders of their sacred soil.

Since the late victory, this repugnance to the war and to its Republican advocates has manifested itself in more ways than one.
The day will come, if the war continues, when such men will leave their homes and enlist on the only side upon which their inclinations or impressions of what is right will permit them to fight.

div4.head: The Manassas failure.
div4.p: The Baltimore South says:

q.p:
We doubt it they who attribute the failure at Manassas to the clamor of the newspapers or members of Congress having driven Gen. Scott to advance before he was ready and contrary to his judgment, think of the obvious reflection of this upon the competency of the General-in-Chief.
If Gen. Scott permits outsiders to upset, his protracted plans, and to drive him to swallow his own strategic offspring, like an unpleasant sow, he would hardly be fit to be trusted again.
Another carefully laid and protracted plan might, just at the culminating point, be thrown into a panic by a newspaper fire upon Gen. Scott's rear.
Gen. Scott may have been grievously disappointed in his Generals, and they may have disobeyed positive orders.
If so, they should be held to strict account, and not honorably discharged, as Gen. Patterson has been, on account of the expiration of his term.
But in justice to Gen. Scott we must believe that he ordered the advance, because in his own judgment the proper time had come to make it.

div4.head: A New Georgia Legion.
div4.p:
Colonel W. B. Gaulding, of Liberty county, informs the editor of the Savannah Republican of his intention to raise a legion for the pending war. It is his purpose to raise not less than 1,000 nor more than 1,500 men, from the counties of Southern Georgia, comprising infantry, cavalry and artillery in just proportions, and to offer them to the President for such service as will be most effectual in aid of Southern independence.
The Republican says Col. Gaulding has devoted much attention to military science, and is enlisted heart and soul in the cause of the South; they will hardly find a leader more anxious to lead them to glory.
He was to have left for Richmond on Friday, in order to perfect the necessary preliminaries.

div4.head: The Rockbridge troops.
div4.p: A correspondent of the Richmond Whig thus performs an act of justice to the Rockbridge troops:

q.p:
I was surprised to see that in an account in your paper of the fight at Rich Mountain, purporting to give a statement of the companies engaged in the action, no mention is made of Captain Curry's company, from this county.
Curry and his company or a part of it at least, were in that fight, and behaved most gallantly.
Curry was badly wounded and taken prisoner.
Several of his men were killed and a number wounded.

In the fight near Martinsburg, the gun which did such fatal execution upon the enemy was worked entirely by a detachment of the Rockbridge Artillery, under Capt. Pendleton, yet they have not been mentioned, at present, as I think, by the Richmond papers.

In the great battle of the 21st, four Rockbridge companies — to wit., the College company, under Capt. White (James): the Rifle company, under Capt. Letcher; the Grays, Capt. Updike, and the Rockbridge Artillery, under Capt. Pendleton, besides Yeatman's company, more than half from Rockbridge — were in the hottest of the fight, and drove the Zouaves before them at the point of the bayonet.
I believe Captain M. X. White's horse company were also in the fight, but I have received no account of it.

div4.head: Lincoln's Cabinet.
div4.p:
The following is from the New York Herald.
It would not surprise us much if the people of the "whole North" yet got to fighting amongst themselves, and thus fulfill John Cochrane's prophecy in his Richmond speech last winter:

The indignation of the whole North is aroused against the Cabinet of President Lincoln, and its removal is demanded on grounds so imperative that they will be insisted upon, until the incompetent and untrust worthy persons who surround the Executive shall have been deprived of the responsible positions they occupy.
Every day developed some new corruption or instance of favoritism and misrule.
It is alleged, with grounds of credence that cannot be disputed, that the motives for leaving our regiments so badly commanded have been in a great measure personal.
This should all be made to cease at once, and a new regime should commence which will put the efficient army officers now languishing in inactivity in the places which are theirs by right.

div4.head: Cut, Wiston.
div4.p: The Northern papers publish the following,
but fall to inform us how they learnt that the captive Colonel is "surrounded by his West Point classmates," Perhaps they are prisoners with him:

Col. Wilcox. of the 1st Michigan Regiment, who was wounded and left on the field, has been heard from and is safe.
He was shot through the arm, and otherwise injured.
He was captured and sent to Richmond, where he now is. He is surrounded by his old West Point classmates, and is receiving the best of treatment.
His wife left Alexandria for Detroit Saturday morning, in good spirits, and greatly relieved in mind.

div4.head: A peace proposition.
div4.p:
In the Washington House of Representatives, on Monday last, Mr. Cox, of Ohio, offered a resolution declaring that although certain States of the Confederacy were violently resisting the authority of the Government, yet in accordance with the rules of civilized warfare, and with the spirit of our institutions, the door should be left open for the peaceable return of such States as should manifest a desire to resume their allegiance, and proposing the appointment of a Peace Commission of one from each State to report such amendments to the Constitution of the United States as should tend to secure that end; and that Congress appoint the Hons.
Edward Everett, Franklin Pierce, Millard Fillmore, Martin Van Buren, T. Ewing, J. Guthrie, and Reverdy Johnson, a Commission, to meet at Louisville in September next an equal number of Commissioners to be appointed by the Confederate States, in order to determine upon an amicable adjustment of the existing national difficulties.
The resolution was negatived.

div4.head: Lincoln's men in Baltimore.
div4.p: The Baltimore Exchange, of Tuesday last, furnishes a number of items about the Hessians in that city, from which we select the following:

q.p:
On Sunday afternoon several soldiers were passing near Washington Monument, when one of them, who had a musket in his hands, walked to a position near the base of the Monument, raised his musket, and, after taking deliberate aim at the status of Washington, fired.
As he brought his weapon down he remarked to a comrade, "Well, there is an end of old Washington." His ire was no doubt excited by the fact that the statue stands with its back to the North, with its arms outstretched to the South.

Some of the vice-policemen of the Southern dictrict yesterday arrested at the camp of the Zouaves, who came to the city from Fortress Monroe on Sunday, a negro man named Elijah Butler, a slave of Mrs. Butler, of Hampton, Va.; also a slave man named Henry Methuselah, owned by James Downey, of Hampton, Va., upon the charge of being runaways.
Fifteen other negroes, who subsequently proved themselves to be free, were arrested in the camp, but were released.
The slaves were retained for their owners.

The streets were pretty well crowded yesterday with drunken soldiers, most of them from the regiments which have recently arrived from Fortress Monroe.
The Third Regiment men were quite prominent in the street cars, using the most profane and obscene language in the presence of ladies and children.
They appear to be an ill-bred set of fellows, who would be no loss to any community.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
It has thus far been found almost impossible, (says the New York Herald,) to gather the debris of the Grand Army into the former encampments of the several regiments that participated in the precipitate retreat to Washington.
Thousands of men are loafing about the city in the most independent fashion.
Many of the officers continue to set a bad example by persisting in the enjoyment of hotel comforts, instead of reporting for duty and trying to rally their men, and infuse them once more with a spirit of order and discipline.

Friends of the Administration, (says the New York Express) are anxious to see the loan bill so amended as to allow the Secretary to borrow at any price.
The experience of Monday shows that a contingency may arise when 7 per cent. will not command money.
The Secretary should certainly have his hands free, in order to carry on his Department properly.

The London Telegraph, in an article on American affairs, concludes thus:"We have never feared that our transatlantic brethren would permit Lincoln and Seward to cancel the work of Washington and Jefferson."

A large number of the cotton manufactories of New England have closed, and others will shortly suspend operations.
The cotton and woolen mills of Philadelphia are nearly all closed.

A wealthy gentleman at Worcester, who has a nephew in the rebel army at Sewell's Point, has sent a letter to Gen. Butler, offering $500 for the head of his traitorous relation.
So says the Boston Post.
An exchange says,"We give the telegraphic news from Washington for what it is worth." That is an unappreciable small value — like the imperceptible continuation of a point.

Col. C. F. Smith, lately Principal at the Virginia Military Institute, has taken charge at Craney Island, in place of Col. Richardson.
Both of these gentlemen are superior officers.
We understand that Capt. Wm. M. Levy has been elected Colonel of the Second Regiment of Louisiana Volunteers.
The resignation of Lieut. Colonel W. W. Mackall, U. S. A., of Maryland, has been accepted.

div3.head: An infamous proceeding.
div3.p: The Baltimore Exchange, of the 30th, has the following editorial upon an act of despotism which we briefly noticed yesterday:

q.p:
Yesterday afternoon, Messrs. Howard, Gatchell and Davis, three of the Police Commissioners of this city, together with seven other persons, most of whom are citizens of Maryland, were placed on board the steamer Joseph Whitney, and carried, as is supposed, to New York, there to be imprisoned at the pleasure of Mr. Lincoln.
All of these "State prisoners," as they were termed in the order which directed their removal, have, for some weeks past, been lying in Fort McHenry, meditating, it may be, on the value of civil liberty and the blessings of a constitutional government.
They had been torn from their families and homes without form of law, and have been patiently awaiting the time when the "flag of the free" should cease to sanctify an act of despotism which could scarcely have been perpetrated in Austria with impunity.
They have been looking for the Grand Jury to put in some tangible shape the slanders which have been circulated against them, and they have been prepared to give the lie to their accusers and to maintain their own integrity.
But the Government has failed to make good its insinuations, and a hostile and unscrupulous Grand Jury has adjourned without preferring a single charge against them; and notwithstanding this they have been arbitrarily hurried out of the State, and are to be subjected to confinement in a Government fortress.
There was a time when the voice of the American people would have been lifted up in unanimous and overwhelming protest against this tyrannous proceeding; when their hands would have been prompt to hurl from power the President who had dared for an instant or under any pretences whatsoever to trample down the laws and the Constitution.
In the days when the enlightened freemen of this continent were wont to denounce the despotic measures of Louis Napoleon, and sneer at the slavish submission of the subjects of the Czar, and boast of the spirit with which Americans would resent oppression — in those days there would have been at least an outcry against the usurpations of the miserable faction which has the ear of a congenial and obsequious chief.
But that time has passed, and we fear forever.
A fanatical majority in the North stands ready to applaud any outrage that is perpetrated in its behalf, and a timid and subservient minority, with but an individual exception here and there, basely shrinks from vindicating its self-respect or duty.
But though the people of one section have been thus recreant to the faith of their fathers, the spirit of freedom yet survives elsewhere.
Here in Maryland, where political and religious liberty was first proclaimed, men still hold firmly to the cause of constitutional government.
They will part with their birthright for no paltry mess of pottage, nor will they forego their privileges at the dictation of any people, or the bidding of any Administration.
Mr. Lincoln has not fortresses enough under his jurisdiction to contain the citizens of Maryland, who are ready to risk life, and all that they hold most dear, in defence of their rights as freemen.--In their behalf, therefore, we here record another protest against the latest and most infamous act of oppression which an unscrupulous and foresworn Government has perpetrated in our midst.

div3.head: Trade in New York.
div3.p: --Speaking of the dry goods trade, the N. Y. Express says:

q.p:
The volume of business is very small, and dullness continues to form the most prominent feature of the trade.
Domestic cotton remains exceedingly quiet, but the bulk of the stock is held for higher rates, owing to the increased value of the raw material.
There have been stoppages among the New England mills, but still the production is more than equal to the demand.
Some descriptions of woolens for army purposes still find a moderate sale, but otherwise there is scarcely anything doing.
Shawls are likely to be produced in greater abundance and variety for the fall trade.
Prints and ginghams are dull and slow of sale.
There are some small bills of staple foreign goods, but the business is quite limited.

div3.p: The Express has the following in reference to the boot and shoe trade:

q.p:
There is little or nothing doing with the regular trade, and there is less activity for the Army.
Manufacturers are working up very little stock for the fall business, and desirable goods, the stock of which have become reduced, are likely to improve.
It is quite evident that somebody is hurt.

div3.head:
An Englishman's view of Affairs at the sent of war.
[Special Correspondence of the London Herald.]
div3.p:
It is scarcely possible to convey to those on the other side of the Atlantic a correct idea of the enthusiasm that prevails in the Confederate States.
The English nation has such to learn regarding Southern institutions and resources, and people at home must be prepared by and by to have their minds disabused of many old prejudices and preconceived notions, which prevent them from forming right conclusions respecting the present position of men and things in the Southern States.
The civil war, which now threatens to deluge the country with blood, has been long expected.
For years the tendency of things has been hastening the crisis which at length has arrived, and the result of which it is impossible to predict.
The people here complain bitterly of the policy of the North with regard to them; and now that war has been declared they seem prepared and determined to defend their territory and maintain their self government, with whatever sacrifices the struggle may be attended.

During my journey through Tennessee and Virginia, I found but one spirit pervading the inhabitants, and I believe that these States of the Confederacy are perfectly indicative of the feeling and determination that actuate the others.
The call for troops made by President Davis has been readily responded to by all classes.
Youths belonging to the first families have in the country, in many instances, entered the ranks of the Confederate army, while others maintain whole companies at their personal coat.
Clergymen, counsellors, physicians, men, in fact, of the highest social positions, have unhesitatingly given up their homes, quitted their families and resigned their prospects in life to accept the doubtful chances of war. I could narrate many touching incidents which came under my personal observation, such as young men taking leave of their aged parents, husbands of wives, and fathers of children.
In journeying through the country the scenes at the railway depots were often of a heartrending description, and made me feel acutely the horrors of civil war, which now bids fair to decimate the population and turn this beauteous land into universal desolation and woe.

The military ardor and aptitude of the people here are remarkable.
There is no lack of volunteers, for they continue to pour in continuously from the various seceding States.-- All the ordinary resources of the numerous railway companies have failed, so that luggage wagons have to be employed and even temporary cars improvised in order to dispatch troops to the seat of war. It is surprising how, in so short a time, tens of thousands of men could have been drilled, uniformed and equipped, and prepared to meet the enemy.--Many of the costumes are exceedingly becoming, others are picturesque, but most of them are made more fore use than show.
The weapons used by the troops are of a varied character, and embrace everything from a Minnie rifle to a bowie-knife.
In this respect the Federal troops have the advantage, as, from the abundance of rifles at their disposal, they are not compelled to make a virtue of necessity and seize any arms that may be within reach.
One officer said to me the other day that he would pay any amount of money could he but procure one hundred English rifles to give his company.
So far as regard weapons, however, the Confederate army is better off at present than it was some few weeks ago. Arms are being had somewhere, notwithstanding the blockading of the ports, and there is sufficient ammunition, I am told, to last for two campaigns.
There is an abundance of provisions also in the country, although a different impression widely obtains in the North.
Indeed, I know upon the best authority that there are sufficient provisions now stored to supply the army for at least six months. The last and principal purchase of stores was fortunately completed the day before the blockade was proclaimed.

The city of Richmond presents a singular appearance.
It is literally teeming with soldiers, and scarcely a man is to be met with in the streets who does not wear a military costume.
The hotels are crowded to inconvenience, and one perpetual round of excitement prevails "from early morn to dewy eve."--Business, as a matter of course, is entirely suspended, and every one is eagerly looking forward to the issue of the present struggle, and wondering what course England and France--but more especially the former — will pursue with regard to the existing complications between the belligerent States.
The South looks confidently to Great Britain for her countenance and recognition, believing that eventually such a course of policy would prove mutually beneficial, and hasten the termination of the struggle in which this country is now unhappily engaged.

The object of the Confederate army in evacuating Harper's Ferry was to co-operate with troops in the rear, and especially with those under command of General Beauregard at Manassas Junction, which opposes the advance of the Federal army from Alexandria.
After this movement the enemy retired from Romney, a position which he had only taken the day before, and fell back upon Cumberland, about one hundred and thirty miles from Winchester, which city the forces at Harper's Ferry now occupy.
This strategic movement on the part of the Confederate army is much applauded, for it is likely to interrupt very seriously the plans of attack formed by General Scott.
Every one here expects that a serious and sanguinary battle will take place in a very few days.

div3.head: Murder of a whole family.
div3.p: --On Tuesday evening last, says the Cincinnati Enquirer, between the hours of 12 and 1 o'clock, the most fiendish, murder it has been our duty to record for a long time took place at Maysville, Ky. An old gentleman by the name of Cobb was known to be in possession of about $200 by a brace of villains named Collins and Moore, and in order to get it they made an attack on the old gentleman, his wife, and two sons, aged fifteen and eighteen years.

The old gentleman and the two sons were killed on the spot, but the old lady was lingering yesterday morning, and faint hopes were entertained of her recovery.
She gave the information who the murderers were.
A large body of the inhabitants turned out in hot pursuit; but, up to the time our informant left, they were yet uncaptured.

div3.head: Don't like those taxes.
div3.p:
--The Cincinnati Enquirer has information from a reliable source, that there is "not a little talk and some warm feeling" manifested on the subject of taxes, in a neighboring district of Indiana.
It is asserted that heavy sacrifices of property will not be quietly submitted to, and sales will be prevented by combinations not to bid, nor to permit others to bid on property offered by tax collecting officers.

The Enquirer concludes as follows:"The feeling pervades all political parties.
We make no comment on this condition of the public mind.
It foreshadows some of the troubles of the future.
When the delirium of the fever, brought about by the acts and frauds of those in power, shall abate, the people will be amazed at their own recent follies, and, we fear, will rush to the other extreme of infuriated madness against the authors of their calamities."

div3.head: Death of James M. Evans.
div3.p:
--The painful intelligence reached this place on Monday, of the death of Mr. Jas. M. Evans--the result of the unfortunate accident of which we gave an account in our last issue.
He died near Monterey.
Highland county, on Thursday last.
Mr. E. had been residing for two years past in Texas, teaching school; but when the war began he hastened to Virginia to enroll himself among the gallant defenders of her soil, and soon after arriving here attached himself to the Randolph Guards, Capt. Cobb.
Brave, gallant, generous, his company have lost by his death a noble soldier and kind-hearted comrade.-- Farmville Journal.

div3.head: Famine among the Indians.
div3.p:
--A Canadian paper says that the Indians living near the Moisie have sent a petition to the Government, which is couched in very characteristic language, and sets forth that the whole tribe is in great distress from want of food and other necessaries of life.
From other advices we gather that the famine is truly extreme, and that the Indians have been reduced even to cannibalism.
Supplies of flour, pork, &c., as well as gunpowder and shot, are to be sent down to them from Quebec, to the value of about $200, which will relieve their distress for the present.

div3.head: Texas moving to the Assistance of Missouri.
div3.p:
--The Fort Smith Times, of the 17th ult., learns that the Texas regiment of horse, expected at that place, would arrive in four or five days. There are about five hundred besides the regiment, coming as independent companies; making in all 1,600 men, with a large park of artillery, the whole of them well armed.
The Times further learns that there are at least 5,000 Texans determined to go into Missouri to help that State.

div3.head: The Memphis shot.
div3.p:
--The new shot, of Memphis invention, which is intended to rotate like the Minnie ball, is in progress.
Some modifications have been made which involve important theoretical principles, and which, we believe, will show a great advance on the first experimental shot.
Gen. Polk views the new weapon with interest, and in a few days it will be tested.-- Appeal.

div3.head: Gone to smash.
div3.p: --At the examination of a boy of nine years of age for admission to one of the public schools in a suburban town, the teacher, after a satisfactory result in reading and spelling, asked: "What do you know about the United States?" The youngster promptly replied, "Don't know nothing, nor nobody does — all gone to smash."--English Paper.

--An affray occurred at Goshen Hill, S. C., on Saturday last, between Mr. R. S. Chick, a member of the South Carolina Legislature, and Mr. Lafayette Hunter, in which the former received a ball in the lungs from a pistol in the hands of the letter.
The wound, it is believed will prove fatal.

div3.head: The Bartow Artillery.
div3.p: --The Griffin Georgian says "a noble band with an immortal name" is now organising in that city, and will leave in a few days for the seat of war.

div3.head:
From Norfolk.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
The enemy are undoubtedly leaving Newport News.
I learn from a gentleman from Camp Jackson, directly opposite that point, that on Tuesday he distinctly saw them striking their tents and going seaward in steamers, which lay in readiness for them.
During the day, five ships were off the News and one large steamer off the Point.
The capture of the privateer that lately sailed from our city is positively confirmed, two steamers coming up and boarding her. She was taken off Hatteras.
Paschal Schisano, a relative of the French Consul here, was among the crew taken.

I am informed by a gentleman from Pinner's Point, whose opportunities of observation are good, that balloon ascensions from Old Point are of frequent occurrence.
They are evidently in search of our masked batteries.

It is gratifying to know that our country friends are engaged in making uniforms for our soldiery, while the delicacies of the farm are sent in profusion.
Could Abe witness this fact alone, he would forever abandon the idea of starving out the South.

Our crops, too, are promising, exceeding expectation, and our farmers with one opinion assert it the largest they have ever known, while our Heavenly Father seems particularly beneficent in the bestowal of other blessings.
Our markets exhibit abundant supplies of every kind, and I cannot but think that God is smiling upon our land.

Divine worship will be held at all the churches on Sunday.
We are glad to hear this, and hope the arrangement will be made general.

One visiting this section cannot but be impressed with the willingness of our blacks in serving the Confederacy, by the amount of work they perform each day. Many, too, have come from a distance with our companies to share with them the trials of camp life and to battle against the foe. A late visit to one of the regiments assured me, however, how happy and contented they appeared.

I regret to announce the death of another of our gallant soldiers from Alabama.
He died at the Hospital of St. Vincent, in this city.
His remains, under a detachment of his late fellow comrades, were taken to Portsmouth yesterday afternoon, and were sent on the cars to his distant home this morning.

The trial of young Hughes, charged with the killing of Lieut. Adams, comes up again to-day.
Luna.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
the vandals in Centreville Church — a contrast.
div3.p:
Since the battle at Manassas I stepped into the Episcopal Church at Centreville, and was greatly shocked by the sight it presented.
The chancel had been torn to pieces.
Nearly every spot on the walls, as high as it was possible for a man to reach, was covered with large fire coal sketches and inscriptions, a few specimens of which I will give you. Jefferson Davis is represented as hanging on a gallows with a most disgusting inscription below.
In another place he was represented with his arms stretched out, as if nailed to a cross, and lastly he was portrayed as if dropping into a coffin, with the words above, "Old Jeff.
going into the box." Above the pulpit, in large letters was "Death to traitors — thus saith the Lord." In another place "God damn the South." "Death to traitors and rebels — Amen." The last inscription I shall notice, and the one that made the deepest impression on me, was in the following words: "Death to all of Secessionist, Senterville, Virginia, July 20th, 1861.--by God." The most of these interesting inscriptions were probably made the day before the great battle.

As I walked from the church with a sad heart, meditating on the deep degradation of fallen nature, I stepped into the hospital where were collected a large number of the wounded Yankees; and there I saw our own people striving to the extent of their ability to retrieve their sufferings and promote their comfort.
They were laid upon comfortable beds, and every attention given them which their necessities required, and a guard was kept at the door to exclude all spectator whose services were not required in the well conducted establishment.
I need not say how deeply I was impressed by the contrast which these two churches — less than two hundred yards apart — presented.

The decision of the court-martial in the case of this gentleman was made known here yesterday.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--For the delivery to me of my Carriage Driver, Beverly. He is twenty-seven years old; color, black; six feet high; face covered with short beard, and moustache; large eye-brows and curling eye-lashes.
He probably travels in a dark grey mixed summer coat, or blue cloth with brass buttons, and carpet-bag.
He says he has read Shakespeare, and may travel with a forged pass, and shave off his beard when he reads this.
He has relatives at Dr. R. H. Stewart's, in King George, and at Mrs. Dr. Frank Taliaferro's, in Orange, with whom he has been recently corresponding by letter.
His object being evidently to escape, he is doubtless lurking about the shore of the Potomac, or making his way Northward, and may be about our encampments.
The above reward will be paid if caught over fifty miles from Fredericksburg; otherwise, $59.

div3.head: Valuable Pickling Recipes.
div3.p:
Good for Pickling Peaches and Tears--Pare the fruit, then and one-half pound sugar to every pound of fruit.
Put them in a j layer of fruit and then a sprinkling of sugar, and let them stand all night.
To the j tuns expressed, add vinegar enough to cover them cook a short time, and they are done.
Spice as you please.
I learn from a German lady (an excellent housekeeper,) that a piece of horse radish root put into the jar with any kind of pickles, will prevent any scum from rising.
We have only to try it to prove it,

Watermelon Pickles--Ten pounds of watermelon rinds boiled in pure water until they are tender; draft the water off, then make a syrup of two pounds of sugar, one quart of vinegar half an ounce of cloves, one ounce of cinnamon.
The syrup to be boiled and poured over the melon rinds boiling hot. Drain the syrup off and let it come to a boil, and pour it over the melon three days in succession.
The rinds prepared in this way far surpasses any pickle.
I ever tasted.
It will keep from one year to another.

Tomato and onion Pickles--To one quart of vinegar, add half a pound of brown sugar, half an ounce of cloves, and one ounce of cinnamon buds.
Select small onions, boil in the vinegar three minutes, skim them out; when cool, lay them down in a crock, first a layer of onions, and then tomatoes, (the small plum tomato is the best,) and when the vinegar is cold pour it over them and sit in a cool place

Pickled Cucumbers--Wash and cover them with a cloth; turn them over a weak brine, boiling hot; cover closely.
Let them remain a few days, then rinse the brine from them and remove to cold vinegar, with horse radish and spices to taste; keep covered closely.

Ripe Tomatoes--Pick them before ripe enough to be sold; wash and prick them; make a brine so strong it will not dissolve all of the sall; boil and skim, and when cold pour it on the tomatoes.
Let them stand eight days, pour off and put on a weak vinegar, which let remain the same length of time, then remove, put on strong vinegar, and whatever success suit your taste; tie no and put away.--You will have nice pickles, and those that will keep.
Green Tomatoes--Take tomatoes after they have grown to their full size, and slice them thin; scald them an instant in salted water; then lay them in a jar with vinegar, cloves and cinnamon.

div3.head: Making Counterfeit coin in Peison
div3.p:
--A convict named Souchey has been arrested at N, N. Y. upon a very singular charge.
It appears that he recently completed a term of sentence in the State prison, at Auburn, and before leaving that institution, was taken in custody on a charge of making and issuing bogus coin while confined in the prison.
When he was arrested in the prison a search of his truck revealed the existence of a false bottom, under which was found a complete kind of burglars' tools, which he had made during his imprisonment.
He had plainly intended to set up business as a house-breaker on recovering his liberty.

div3.head: Troubles in Russia
div3.p:
--Insult to the Emperor The Emperor of Russia's position at present does not appear to be very enviable.
It seems that when the Emperor Alexander entered the theatre at Moscow all the company quitted it, as if they obeyed a preconcerted signal.
It is added that the Emperor's aids de camp were insulted by the crowd.
But, what is still more sell us, the insurrection among the peasants is expending every day, and it is assuming alarming proportions.
He herto the troops have acted without hesitation against the insurgents, but fears as to their fidelity are now beginning to be entertained.
